editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ZELINDA: An Excellent New ROMANCE. Tranlated from the French of Monieur De Scudery. By T. D. Gent.
LONDON, Printed by T. R. and N. T. for James Magnes and Richard Bentley, in Ruel-Street in Covent-Garden near the Piazza's, Anno Dom. 1676.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
THe World is grown as unconcionable to s men of Wit, and Parts, as greedy Houe-Wives to poor Cotermongers; though they have never o much Trah for a little Money, they mut have a Cat into the Bargain; a Prologue, or a Preface: and they expect Wit in them too, though there is none any
where ele. This extortion was a while gratified, but the Nine Siters are o beggered with the Maintenance of their Multiplicity of Gallants, that the inatiable Critick mut take down-right Railing, for Wit: And I hould but imitate my betters, if I rak'd in the honour'd ahes, and recited the little failings of my ingenious Predeceors, thoe renowned and never to be forgotten Authors of Amadis de Gaul, the Knight of the Oracle, Bevis of Southampton, and Unfortunate Jack.—Or I might with others tax the impudence of my Contemporary
Scriblers, for pretending o audaciouly to Wit and Poetry, when none has more confidence or les merit then my elf.—No! I am for Peace and Policy; Controveries and Diputes among Divines, make Tub-Preachers and Atheits;—Enquiries, Anwers, Replys and Rejoynders between Doctor. N. and Doctor. S. concerning each others Practice, expoed the failings of both to Vulgar contempt, and raied the repute of Quacks and hedge Doctor: while Wil. Pen and the Anabaptit were hurling Fire & Brimtone at one another in
Aldergate-Street, Muckleton damned them both over a Pot of Ale. I ay, let the green Faggot-ticks of Poetry cling together in the band of Amity, and inpite of the fierce Criticks puffing, they may His, Pipe on, and be Courted, while he blows his Nails: But when the intetine fire of Envy diolves the nion, by giving light and pleaure to others, they conume themelves. I think this is a good imile now.—Let us conceal each others Faults, and be great; and let not him that is found out, and jutly condemned, dicover all the
ret to ave himelf, like a faint-hearted Padder.——Why hould the Taylor call the Miller a Thief.—

Book-Sellers too are grown uch Saucey Materly Companions, they do even what they pleae; my friend Mr. Bentley calls this Piece an excellent Romance; there I confes his Justice, and Ingenuity. But then he tiles it a Tranlation, when (as Sancho Panca aid in another Cae) 'tis no more o then the Mother that bore me.—Ingrateful to envy his friends Fame! Though Sir Martin fetch his Plot from Preter
John and the Stingies, Warner will manage all.—But I write not for Glory, nor Self-Interest, nor to gratifie Kindnes, nor Revenge; Now the impertinent Critical Reader will be ready to ask, for what then? For that and all other quetions to my prejudice, I will borrow Mr. Bays's anwer, and ay, Becaue—I glad Sir, I will not tell you.—I deire to pleae but one peron in the World, and (as one Dedicates his Labours and Heroes to Calita, another to Urania, &c.) at the feet of her my adored Celia, I lay all my Giants and
Monsters: to any other Cenurer I ay,

p.hi: Non vides id Manticae quod in tergo et.

div.p: But to her I Bow, her favour I Implore; and to her Sentence I ubmit, as becomes her,

closer.signed: Admirer and humble Servant, T. D.

div.head: ZELINDA; A ROMANCE.
div.p:
IN the time when Spain was divided, not only amongt everal Kings, but divers Nations; the Goths, the Moores, and the Spaniards, having each of them a Share: Arragon was ruled by one, who in the midt of thoe Wars that troubled his Neighbours, had jut abilities enough to keep his own Subjects in Peace; and was Famous only for being the Father of him, who is the Subject of this
Hitory. His Wife after having brought him one Son, dyed: At the ame time the Dutches of Barcellona, a Young and Beautiful Princes, had newly lot her Husband, though he was already old. His Council thought it very neceary he hould have more Heirs then one, for his own as well as his peoples Security; and therefore in behalf of all his Subjects, deired him to chooe a Wife to his likeing, either in his own, or his Neighbours Dominions. The Beauty of this Dutches was well known further then Arragon; and beides that in Policy, the occaion was not to be let lip of unwriting to his Kingdom o coniderable a Town as Barcellona; the Kings own inclination made him conceive that Policy the better. Though Roalava had great Beauty, he had yet more Wit than Beauty, o that being already abolute; nothing les then a Crown could have tempted her to think of a econd Marriage; but having an only Daughter as well as he an only Son; She thought this Ma • ch would not make herelf only Queen of Arragon, but her Daughter too, and that he could not be blamed,
if being in the midt of ambitious Neighbours, he ecured her elf by a way o advantagious and Honourable. She eaily then conented, intead of Dutches of Barcellona, to be called the Queen of Arragon; where he was received with the uual joy and Magnificence upon uch occaions: Being Young, Agreeable and Dicreet, She oon governed her Husband, and conequently the Kingdom. Now no buines of Importance was done without her Conent, whoe Satisfaction was the Kings only care; but this great authority he made ue of mot, in that deign of Marrying her Daughter to the Prince, which he was much more deirous of, ince he knew what kind of one he was like to be. Alcidalis was born o propitiouly, and with o many natural advantages; That being a Kings Son, was the leat coniderable: He had a Beauty which won the Hearts of all that aw him, a Wit in his very Childhood not to be equalled, and a greatnes of Mind that made every body repect and fear him: The firt years of Alexander were not more Miraculous than his; and there was not a day in
which he did not ay, or do omething to the atonihment of all about him. Thoe that pretended to skill in Phiognomy, by looking on his Face, foretold glorious and incredible actions; and they that took urer meaures by thoe he had done already, foreaw the Crown of Arragon would prove too little for uch a head: The Queen oberved his Perfections better than any body, and therefore grew extreamly Fond of him, and impatient to bring about her Daughters happines; which he thought conited les in being Queen of Arragon, than Wife to Alcidalis. But how lightly oever we peak of Fortune, we mut allow hers to be the only Widom, and conequently count our own but folly Her deigns are layed o far off, and carried on by ways o impoible to be perceived, that they never fail to ucceed in pite of all our endeavours to the contrary; and he allows us ometimes to throw in her way our vain oppoitions only to have the pleaure of making then o: Thus far he dallied with Roalva but • e • o • ving to be at length too har • for he •
brings from another Country
•
young Child, who though both a tranger and an Orphan) was to ruine all the deigns of this powerful and politick Queen. The Prince of Tenara of a family in Calabria, o Illutrious, as formerly to have given Kings to Naples and Sicily, had o coniderable an Etate newly fallen to him in Arragon, that he reolved to take himelf Poeion of a Right which was a little diputed and loving his Wife extreamly, who was as fond of an only Daughter they had about ix years old, they could not think of parting; and therefore tranported their whole Family to Arragon, where they were received by the King and Queen with all the civility and kindnes due to Strangers of o great Merit and Quality. But oon after the Prince of Tenara grew ick of a dieae that in a few dayes ended him, and left his afflicted wife in o dipairing a condition, as made her not only willing, but likely to follow him. She received from the Queens kindnes, (who began to love her,) all the comfort and aitance which either her afflictions, or affairs were capable of: The Queen had always liked her, but ince this misfortune,
Pity increaing her affection, he loved her tenderly. Fate eldom ravihing our joyes from us, till we have et upon them the highet value, or rather we never prize them enough, till the danger of their being lot makes us do it too much: She lodged her in her own Palace, and took uch care to be perpetually, with her that he eemed to mis a part of her elf when they were aunder. However, all this indulgence of the Queens, (enough to have cured her of any other Dieae) only allayed this, by making her bear it with les depair and impatience: And yet nevertheles, her Husbands death, with the ad circumtances of time and place, was o great a blow, and made o deep an impreion, that all the Queens care and kindnes was unable to preerve her from a dangerous Sicknes; which proceeded for want of Sleep and Nourihment. The Queens trouble was proportionable, who beides her Grief for the los of uch a friend, was not a little concern'd to ee two uch fatal accidents happen in her Dominions, to a Family newly come to dwell there. Phyitians were conjured
to ue their utmot endeavours; but although they did o, her Dieae was too trong for their tronget Remedies; and therefore her own Judgment as well as theirs, giving the fatal warning, he reolved to quit the World with as much tranquility, as that dear pledge he left in it would allow her, which ure could not be great, when he reflected upon the age and place he left her in; An Infant in a trangers Country: While Camilla's thoughts were thus adly imployed, the Queen once asking her how he did? She gently look't up upon her, and taking her by the hand, kied it everal times before he was able to peak a word; but at lat told her he was very enible of the obligations he had to o indulgent a Queen that ince he enquired of her health o kindly, he would preume to tell her, that though he knew death o near, it was not her greatet apprehenion, and that her Daughters helples condition was the reaon why he could not but leave the World uncomfortably; and therefore beg'd leave to manage to the bet her few remaining hours, by eaing her elf of a heavy burden, and powring out or
her own breat into the Queens her dearet and mot tender thoughts: She told her he hould thank Heaven for giving her leave o oon to follow the Prince her Husband, if he were only ure the preent he now made her would be acceptable; a preent of all he held dear and precious in the World: Then having dryed her eyes of tears which thoe lat words had drawn from her, he went on to aure her that amongt all her mieries, he could carce think Fortune her enemy, that had brought her to the honour of uch a Friendhip, by a journey which he hould think properous, were it not for her Lords death, though it proved her own too, ince her kindnes, was a Jewel he could not pay too dear for, and the only thing in the World he valued: But was more comforted with the hopes of her Daughters ucceeding her in that, then in all the Fortunes he left her; and therefore conjured her to look upon her always as the dying preent of one he eteem'd, and not didain to prove a Mother to the Daughter of a friend, whom he hould think in that better provided for, then in the two
Principalities he was Heir to. And then her death would not be unwelcome, ince not unhappy; for Zelinda, who by this change would have the advantage, of being Bred by a Queen every way o extraordinary: Having aid this, he took from under her Pillow a little Box of Jewels, which for her Daughters ake he had always taken care of, and accordingly now put into the Queens hands. Camilla's afflicted condition, and the manner he expreed it in, were both o moving, that the Queen had not been able to refue her requet, though ure of its fatal conequence. She threw her Arms about her, and aured her he received her preent with joy, and upon condition he hould never revoke it, which he hoped her recovery would give her leiure, though not unkindnes to do: That from that moment he reckoned her elf to have two Daughters, between whom he hould no more ditinguih than Twins, of which he did not dipair to have her a Witnes: This cured Camilla's mind, though not her body, and made her life eaier, though not longer; for two
days after he left the World with that Cheerfulnes which the Queens promies gave her; and the Queen capable of no comfort but the hopes of performing them. Thus we ee Zelinda in les then three Months become a perfect Orphan, by burying both her Parents in their Graves, whoe Inheritance they came to enjoy; We ee her but ix years old, in a trange Countrey, a thouand Miles from her own; and what is yet wore in the abolute power of one who was in time to prove her greatet enemy, and the caue of all her Mieries. But none are o afe as thoe in the hands of Fortune, who never fails uch as relie upon her either by choice or neceity: She took into her charge this ditreed Orphan, and o ordered this diatrous beginning, as to make it a means of etting her in the Throne of two mighty Kingdoms. Zelinda was the mot perfect creature Heaven ever made; her Peron was as miraculous as her life, and this Story, though very natural in every other part, is incredible where it peaks of her. Since the Sun went round the World he never aw o exact a Beauty, and in
this Beautiful body, there was a Wit above the imagination of ours, and uch a one as no other body but hers had been worthy of: In the age when others carce pake Words, he poke Sene, and uch as might have become any mouth. At her Birth all the Stars were agreed to contribute their bet influences; And he appeared o Divine a thing, as one could not but imagine her fallen from Heaven by a Miracle: She was o naturally inclined to Good, that doing it, in her was carce a Virtue; and it was not in her power, at leat not without great elf-denyal, to avoid the practice of all things commendable; If we could look into the minds of the mot extraordinary, we hould not find them o faultles as their lives; and though their vertue at lat gets the better, 'tis a victory like thoe in Civil Wars by which they mut needs uffer, ince their Reolutions are no more their own, then the inclinations that oppoed them. But in this perfect Creature, Vertue reigned by Birth, and not by Conquet; and therefore he could never fail of doing well, while he did what he liked bet: Beides thee
perfections which are to be decribed, thoe Names, Charms, and Secret graces, which make us love o often we know not why, Zelinda poet in uch abundance; that he was the general inclination of every man and woman. All her motions were o agreeable, that no others Beauty was half o Charming, and in her gentle Voice there was omthing like Enchantment. Perhaps this is not all that might be, but 'tis certain, all he deerved cannot be expret, and it will be eaily much imagined that where there was o much, there mut be a great deal more. And ince, Madam, by this Decription he appears o very like you, I had as good confes ingenuouly, that in the tory there were o many remarkable things of her, that though I minded it extreamly, I could never have drawn o good a Picture if you had not at before me. Thee were the Arms with which Zelinda was to be victorious, and there needed no other, ince they were enough to Conquer Alcidalis, who would eaily conquer the ret: She was received into Court with o general a joy, that it eemed an Omen of her future Greatnes there, of
which he then took poeion. The Queen who thought her elf uncapable of any comfort ince her Mothers death, found the contrary whenever he was with her, and the Kings affections carce knew a difference between her and his only Son.

Alcidalis and Zelinda, were of that Age in which Painters repreent Cupids, and had all the agreeable Beauties, the greatet Maters in that Art could give them; Their Charms were o equally taking, though extreamly different, and their very childhood was o extraordinary, that none aw them without concluding them Born for one another, and each had been an unparallel'd wonder of the World, if it had not een them together. Indeed though they had the hearts of all that aw them, they could never have been loved equally to their Merit by any but themelves; no Souls but their own being capable of a Paion great enough to deerve theirs. Accordingly the God of love, intending to make his power remarkable by hewing it in perons o extraordinary, ettled it in their hearts o very early, that
they felt it long before they knew it, and were not uffered to pas in quiet that firt part of life, which Nature eems to allow unditurbed by Paions: Thus the firt ight of Zelinda wrought the ame effect upon Alcidalis which it was wont to do upon others, and he made ome impreion upon the heart of Zelinda, which he had never felt before. The Queen in puruance of her great deign, had bred up this Prince with all the artifice imaginable, that might incline him to love her Daughter. His firt pratling was taken advantage of, that he might be ued to call her his Mitris: he was dayly brought to ee her, and thoe about him till took all occaions to commend before him either her Face or Fahion. But his inclinations were not the ame with the Queens, he that had Softnes and Complaiance for all the World, eemed to want it only for her Daughter, and was no where o contrained as in her company: Whether his high Spirit didained to be thus given away without his own conent, or that his Stars, which brought him into the World, for Zelinda gave him a natural
averion to whooever would uurp that place they had deigned her. But from the firt moment he came to Court, and was by the Queen made her Daughters Companion, his mind appeared immediately changed, he was perpetually in the Dutches's apartment, and no where o well pleaed as there. Love to introduce himelf eaily into our ouls, at firt comes alwayes accompanied with Delight and Beauty; and makes no hew of violence or Cruelty, till he knows himelf Mater of the place, and too trongly fixed to fear being dipoet. At firt thee young lovers felt his power in nothing, but an extream pleaure in eeing one another, and then uch a weetnes mixt with joy, pred it elf about their Countenance, that it was very viible their love made them appear more lovely. Zelinda had till then been like others of her age, but now began to be more lively; and Alcidalis when he aw her, was o gay and agreeable, that it look't as if he had reerved for her company ome particular Grace, and the bet of his humour. In that innocent age they enjoyed a pleaant tranquillity of mind
for ome Months, in which they were much happier, then in many more that followed.

But their paions increaed daily with their undertandings, and Love became o powerful, that he quickly made himelf be both felt and undertood; Alcidalis now grew more thoughtful then ordinary, and when Zelinda was abent, with an unuual adnes paid dear for the pleaure of having een her, there was no port for him in any diverions, but thoe he took with her, for eeing her was his only pleaure; or if any thing ele was not indifferent to him, it was talking himelf, and hearing others talk of her. That heart which even from his Childhood was et upon conquering the World, now hath no hopes nor thoughts but of gaining Zelinda; or if ometimes thoe of his former ambition return, it is but with deign of rendring himelf more worthy of her, by laying at her feet as many Crowns as he deerved. When ever he quitted the room, he was as if fallen from Heaven, and next to her company he loved none bet. When alone (which for her
ake he was often) he was perpetually reflecting upon all her words and actions; and having conidered them the everal wayes, they were capable of being turned, drew from them accordingly either hopes or fears; then remembring his own expreions of kindnes, was never atisfied with himelf; ometimes he thought he was too timerous, ometimes too bold, and remained alwayes at lat as much dipleaed with himelf, as pleaed with her: He begun by degrees to give over all thoe recreations he was wont to be fond of, Hunting, which he loved bet, became a dull thing to him when he was not there, and if he till minded his Exercies, it was but to appear more agreeable to her: In a word, he conidered Zelinda as if there had been no Body in the World beides.

Love on the other ide had got into the heart of Zelinda, but had not made o great a progres; whether it were that fearing her high pirit, he durt not make himelf known to her at firt, or that he being the younger by two years, was les enible of that
paion: Yet he was not altogether unconcerned, for when ever he aw the young Prince, he had more care of her beauty and dres than ordinary; he loved the Countes the les, becaue he was deigned for him, and every little repect that out of decencie he paid her, took omewhat from the atisfaction of the fair Zelinda. Yet as he had a Soul, generous, reolute, and infinitely enible, and by conequence capable of none but paions of the ame nature, the merit of Alcidalis formed in it an affection as fair and perfect as it elf.

Love between Perons of o eminent quality (like fire upon a Beacon) is o impoible to be concealed, that it is een a great way off. The affections of Alcidalis and Zelinda was oon oberved by all the World, and a great many perceived they were in Love one with another, before they dicover'd it themelves. In the beginning when Childihnes made their actions les obervable, though they aw one another with great joy, no body thought there was any other Love between them, then that of the innocent diverions they took together.
But as by degrees Zelinda grew more erious, and Alcidalis began to hew himelf mater of a judgment fit to govern his Fathers Kingdom, and a courage capable of conquering any other. There was carce any body in the whole Court, but judged their Souls to be united by o trong a paion, that it would be almot an equal difficulty to part'em from their bodies, or from each other. The Queen who was politick beyond her Sex, and deigned nothing o much as marrying her Daughter to Alcidalis, was the earlyet jealous of Zelinda's beauty, and conequently the firt that took notice of this amour; But having a great confidence in her Interet, and more in her elf, he thought they at lat would be the only Sufferers, and feared no tubborn reitance from minds o tender.

In the mean time the beauty of Zelinda increaed daily; and though it dawned but a while ago, now hone with uch light and lutre, that he eemed to proclaim open War againt the Queen, and all her deigns. On the other ide the young Prince enible of
his birth and parts, began to be weary of living under the lavery of a Governour, and the conduct of a Woman. That heart great and Royal by Nature, when filled with Love, didained any other Empire but Zelinda's; He began to carry his inclinations for her a little more openly, and favoured none but uch as he recommended: He run at the Ring only in her colours, all his motto's poke of her, and he was o proud of her Chains, that he hated all the World hould not ee them; There were none who in their hearts did not favour their affection. The Queen oon began to fear he had dallyed too long with a flame o fatal to all her purpoes, & which now required her utmot care and endeavours to extinguih it: Yet he reolved to trie violent remedies at lat; and trove by all fair means to win upon the dipoition of Alcidales, which he perceived to grow les tractable to her every day than other: She ued all the Arts he could to Eclipe the beauties of Zelinda, and to advance thoe of her own Daughter, whom he daily intructed, both what to ay and do, never uffering her
to appear but with pompe and luter But Zelinda truting till to Nature, whom he had been o much obliged to already, neglected by her elf, was more admired by others, and without any Pearl but thoe of her teeth, or any Rubies but thoe of her lips, and uch other Jewels as a waiting Woman Mue, drees a Poetical Mitres in, out-hone the other, though adorned with all the glories of the Eat; o much the wealth that Heaven betows, Ecclipes whatever the Earth can lend her Favourites.

The Queen eeing the danger of their continuing any longer in the ame place, and dipairing of all other wayes to interrupt their increaing affection, reolves to trye if abence (though it be the greatet torment of a ettled) might not prove the cure of a growing inclination: And to that purpoe, under pretence of ome indipoition, deires leave of the King her Husband to pas two or three Months in Catalonia, and having gained his conent, he commanded all things to be in readines for her journey, and aid, he would have none attend her but the Ladies. This news extreamly
urpried our Lovers, who had never felt the ting, and been only acquainted with the weets of Love, and except ome few apprehenions for the future; which makes but light impreions in minds o young, and full of confidence, their joy had been without trouble, and their inclination without the leat check. Alcidalis was mot concerned, or at leat could wort diemble; there was nothing he would not have attempted to divert this journey, & a thouand extravigances pat through his imagination about it, but eeing the time drawn on, and the Queens reolution invincible, he reolved, at leat not to let Zelinda part without a full and open declaration of his paion for her, which till then, (though all his actions continually proclaimed to her) his words had never preumed to offer the leat hint of: Whether it were that he wanted confiidence, or thought it needles to declare a paion that none could ever hide. The lat night being come, he went on the Queens ide; where, after ome time, he found an opportunity of entertaining Zelinda alone, it was the firt minute
that ever Alcidales knew what fear was. He attempted once or twice to dicover his paion; but having not reolution enough to go on, was fain to turn his dicoure to omething ele, and though at other times he was the gayet Man in the World, near Zelinda he was then the mot perplext. But at lat his heart beating, and his colour perpetually changing, he with a confued and trembling voyce, aid: I do not doubt Ze-Linda; But that you know I love you but; how well, after I have aid all I can, mut till be left to your imagination: I tell you this, that if you find me kill'd by your abence, you may know the nature of your los though your Journey be compos'd but of a few dayes to the ret of the World; they will to me eem many Years, and may perhaps outlat me. If you conider me and your elf, you will find the one too Charming to give a moderate affection, and the other incapable of a weak impreion: From the firt moment I aw you, my paion was at the ame height, that time, or favours ever advanc't any other to: And ince every Look, every Word, every
Motion of yours has added omewhat to it; whilt I was a Child, I cou'd not expres it to you; and ince I never durt; and now I tremble only in aying, I adore you; and if I read not uddenly, omething favourable in your eyes for me, I hall oon want the power to let you know the greater part of that I have to ay. At thoe words, he who had till then kept her eyes upon the ground, look't gently up at him; Alcidalis eem'd to have received a new life, and thus continued. Though inclination be but a blind guide; I mut needs confes my elf infinitely fortunate, in that which led me to adore the incomparable Zelinda; in whom I hourly dicover uch eminent perfections, as may change even an Averion to its contrary: Judge then what a paion I mut have conceived for her, ince it was o advantagiouly born, and has been o continually improv'd: I confes freely, Humility is a vertue that you alone have made me acquainted with, I ever thought the whole world too narrow for me; but now I think my elf, and that world infinitely below you; I know the lat
thing that you conider in me, is my Quality; If I poes any thing worthy of you, 'tis my heart, which I offer to you; and which I can ay with confidence, to be Great and Generous enough to merit a place in yours. I would not praie it thus, were it any longer my own: But now I think advantagiouly of it, as I mut ever do of all things that belong to you. It never had but two deignes, whereof the firt, and that which entertained its Childhood, was the Conquet of the World: But ince it has been more apiring, and more reaonable, it has deired Zelinda. Here he topt, and waited for her anwer, who in the condition he was in, had much a do to get out thee few words. Sir, I am o atoniht at a dieoure of this nature from you; and to find the eyes of the whole Court upon us, that I deire you will give till my return to make you an anwer: Which I beg of you to believe, I wih may he very udden: Every body oberved omewhat extraordinary between them, but the Queen epecially, whom their Converation
made very uneaie; he roe from her place, and Smiling upon Alcidalis ay'd, Sir you entertain Zelinda o eriouly and with o much concern in your face, that I doubt you have had ome little quarrel; if it be o, make me Judge, and i'le ee her do you reaon before he goes. Alcidalis having overcome the firt difficulty of declaring his Paion to Zelinda, was impatient of being interrupted, o that without almot looking toward the Queen; he anwered her carelesly Madam I injured Zelinda o jut, that i • he had required me, I would yet deire no Judge but her elf, and what quarrel oever we have, I hall till have a wore to them that go about to part us. This harp reply was oberved by all the Court; but the Queen who was concerned at it eemed lea •• to mind it, and chang'd the Dicoue. The next morning Zelinda was hurri'd away before Alcidalis could pea • to her, and left him in the firt great affliction he ever knew; it was all as great to her, and more inuppor •
able, in that he was forced to digui ••
her ene of it, and cover alo with a cheerful Face a dicontented Mind, hiding her mifortune in publick with as many Smiles, as he lamented it in private with Teares.

Of all the troubles that love brings with it, abence is one of the mot enible, there are ome violent; ome harper pains, as that of jealouy, but none o hard to bear; and that o opprees all ort of vigour.

She was no ooner gone, but Alcidalis hut himelf up in his Chamber, threw himelf upon the Bed; wherewith a torme of Sighs, and a Sea of Tears, he grieved for her, rather as dead then Abent; not conidering that love takes ever back with Interet the joyes be lends, and lets few of his Debtors ret o long as he had done him: Having continued even or eight dayes without eeing any but the King, and him as eldom as his duty would permit, he reolved to follow Zelinda, and rather Perih in an attempt towards happines, then tamely expect a certain death from her abenc •
After Hebrius one of the mot famous Rivers
of Spain, has pat along the Walls of Saragoa (as if there were nothing ele worthy of him in Arragon) he takes the way of Catalonia, where receiving in his paage many rivolets, to make his entry more tately into the Sea; he comes at lat within half a League of Tortoa: The Countrey he waters is very Fruitful, and full of Trees, which is the more agreeable, in that the ret conits of dry naked Places, and Mountains corcht up by the heat of the Sun, fifteen Leagues from his Mouth. He paes through a Valley two Leagues long, and proportionably broad on both ides, encompat with Mountaines: Thoe of Catalonia keeps it from the North-Winds, o that it is always Green, and the Inhabitants never feel that Winter, which they ee continually upon the neighbouring Hills: 'Twas in this Paradice that Zelinda pat her Purgatory; and where the Pallace of the Queen tood; She alone was ad where all nature appeared to mile; and lot hourly • hat luter, which every thing there abouts eem'd to have borrowed
of her; The abence of Alcidalis troubled her continually, and her Melancholly was not confin'd to the preent, but had likewie ome preages of the ills to come, he aw her Fortune, and her elf, and Alcidalis more dear then both, in the power of the Queen; She conidered, that though the courage of the Prince was great, and his love greater, his Authority was yet but weak. That he would never be uffered to depie the Countrey of Barcelonia, which fortune offered him o opportunely with the Queens Daughter: To Marry an Orphan, and a Stranger, who had no Fortune, no Support, but afar off, that he alone would not be able to reit the commands of the King, the good of the Kingdom, and the deignes of the Queen, who governed both, that whilt they were Children, though all favour'd their affection, yet none approv'd their Marriage: That many look't upon her already as an enemy of the State, and the Torch that was ooner or later to et the whole Kingdom on a Flame: Thee, and uch
thoughts continually tormented her, and the further he look't into the future, the more terrible her propect grew. One day above the ret, as he was walking with the Queen in an extream thick Wood, he lipt from the company, attended only with one Maid, 'twas no mall eae to her to have the liberty of venting her Grief; which at other times he almot doubled by diembling, and reflecting on various Accidents of her life, what he had already uffered, and what he was hourly threatned with: Her Melancholly poet her o entirely, that without thinking of the way he found her elf by the Banks of Hebroes: The Charms of o delightful a place, the weetnes of the Air, and the pleaure he took in being alone, invited her to continue her walk; but fearing the Queen might wonder at her abence, he topt when the noie of a Horne, which eemed not to be far off, made her turn her head towards a Neighbouring Mountain, where he aw as he thought, two men clos'd, and falling together from a Rock; but
upon a econd view, he found it was a Bear and a man; when immediatly on the place from whence the other fell, he aw a young man very well Hort, leap down after them, the trength of the Hore, the addres of the Horeman, or the Fortune of both, was uch, that they took no hurt; he immediately kills the Bear at one troak, with his Javelin, and aves his friend. This generous Action o urprized Zelinda, that he was almot angry that any but Alcidalis had done it: But he that was on Horeback came towards her, and pat the River in a place where it was Fordable. She began to think it was Alcidalis, but not being perfectly aured; he askt her Woman if he knew that Gentleman; who anwered: Madam, a far off we might have known him by his Action; but now we may ee it is the Prince. As he came nearer, atonihment, fear, and joy, all at once, o eied Zelinda, that he could not readily find words to receive him with, The Prince who had a longer time to prepare himelf, though not without
ome diorder, aid; Madam, you are not to wonder at any confidence, from a man that is already guilty of that, of having declared he loves you; your lat words gave me an impatiency, that turned every hour of your abence into an Age, and I had been unworthy of your return or anwer, had I been able longer to expect either: What I aid then, was but what I mut always think, and if it were ever Criminal, am come to tell you, I am till Impenitent. Sir aid he, if you will give me the leiure to make you the anwer I promied you, when I left Saragoa: Then (finding her elf Bluh, and that he perceived it) he went on thus: This Colour that ries in my Face, proceeds rather from that I am going to ay omewhat I never did before, then from a thought that I do therein any thing againt my honour, I know not whether it be always a hame for a Maid to owne he loves, but if ever it were excuable, ure it is in me. I will not ay that my Stars, or your eminent Qualities forc't me to it; thoe are pretences that any one may ue; I will only urge uch as are more peculiar to my
cae. I lov'd you Alcidalis before I knew it was a fault, and conceived an affection for you before I was capable, of thoe Laws that forhid it to our Sex. None can blame me for giving entrance to a Paion, which I eem'd rather to have found there, then received into my heart, and which has been o long here; that I can no more remember its Birth more then my own. The firt inclination I ever had, was for you, and elf love o early, and o natural in all the world, came to me later, then my friendhip for Alcidalis: My Reaon (which appeared not in a great while after) found it o well ettled that it almot lookt like rebellion to attempt any thing againt it; beides it eemed o innocent, and o jut, that he rather endeavoured to trengthen, then oppoe it, I ay all this to excue it both to you and myelf, and to make you know that the oul the freet from weaknes, and mot reaonable in the World, might have been urpris'd, as mine was: If you are pleaed that I love you, thank not me, but Heaven that would have it o. If
you are at all obliged to me, it is only for owning of it to you: Thus, though I had not the power of extinguihing my affection, I had certainly that of concealing it, I could have diembled it all my life time, or as mot of our Sex do, have howne it you by little, and little; after having made you long deire it; were it not unreaonable or unworthy either of you or me: It would never he time to dicover it; but one the contrary, if it be only uch as Zelinda ought to have for Alcidalis. Why hould I not from this Minute, give him the joy of knowing, and being aured of it. I tell you then I love you Alcidalis. and though I ay it with Bluhes, I do it without hame, I accept that heart which you gave me; which I eteem a Treaure far beyond the Crown you promied with it, I am pleaed, to find all the qualities of your mind truly Royal; but I could wih your Birth were les o; for I fear Fortune to take that Crown away, which is the thing I leat eteem in you, will rob me one day of all the ret. I ee from this hour all the Misfortunes that threaten me, I know your love will caue the hatred of the Queen, but he that
hath to her own the heart of Alcidalis can fear nothing: I will reit all with a reolution that hall amaze you; and ince Heaven decreed I hould have affection, I will accompany it with uch a Vertuous Contancy, that what is ordinarily reprocht in my Sex, hall be in me eteemed, and wondred at. Alcidalis from the very firt Minut he began, had till hearkened to her as one whoe fate depended on her Dicoure, finding it much more to his advantage then he durt have hoped, was o far from being able to expres his joy, that he even wanted words for an acknowledgment: But after a while coming to himelf, & finding her that followed out of ight, he put one knee on the ground; but as he began to peak, the Queen appeared near; the thicknes of the buhes having hid her approach, o that he aroe again as oon as poible. Zelinda was extreamly troubled to be o unluckily urpried: And aid, Sir, you will I fear have caue to repent this unneceary humility. Madam, aid he, I do already, but 'tis only that 'twas no earlier adret: Whilt they were talking
the Queen advanc't, and Alcidalis coming up to her, he received him with a Countenance o gay, and full of atisfaction, that Zelinda her elf could do no more. After the firt Complements were over, the Prince having told her how the Chace bringing him within even or eight Leagues, he thought himelf obliged to kis her hands; the Queen eemed to thank Fortune, for having conducted him o near her. But Sir, aid he, I believe you are already paid for all the trouble you have given yourelf, for its to be imagined the favour that Zelinda granted you jut now, was not inconiderable: Since you thanked her upon your Knees for it, as we aw; truly it made me not know you at firt, and I thought it had been ome of your Servants, but I am very glad it was none but yourelf who received that atisfaction: Pray let us know what it was, that we may partake in your Good-Fortune, and thank her with you. Zelinda did not grow red upon this, becaue he had continued o, ince her dicoure with Alcidalis, and fearing what the Queen
aid, might urprize him; womens Wits being ever readiet on uch occaions; he anwered and aid. Madam, I was asking Alcidalis ome News of Saracoa, he (who without doubt, was thinking of his Hunting) did not anwer me, I then reproacing him with his heedleenes and Silence, he kneel'd to me of a uddain, and thought by other exces of Civility to repair the neglect he had hew'd in not replying ooner to what I aid. 'Twas very civil in him, aid the Queen, and becaue you believe the Prince is thinking of his Hunting till, you have taken care to anwer for him. Zelinda eeing the Queen pres her o hard quitted the Dicoure. But Alcidalis perceiving the pain he was in, came to her aitance as he had done before to his, and began a relation of ome little indipoition, the King had uffered in her abence, o that the Dicoure was quite changed. The good humour Zelinda had put him into, made him entertain the Queen with infinite complyance, and addres himelf more then formerly to her Daughter. But our young Lovers were not cunning enough
to deceive her; he perceived the alteration and concluded the gayety of Alcidalis, and the repect he treated her Daughter with, to be but effects of ome obliging aurance he had obtained from Zelinda, and from that moment took the reolution of parting them. The Prince went the next day to Saragua, whether the Queen was forced to return eight dayes after, this abence was much more upportable to him then the other, for he had in it the comfort of knowing he was belov'd by the peron in the World he mot eteem'd, they pat ome Months o well, and with uch Tranquility, that Alcidalis could almot have forgot there was a happines beyond it.

But there is a fatal point which nothing can ever pas, and fortune is ometimes as weary of the joyes of Lovers, as of the weight of Empires, the highet happines has this fault that its then nearet its end. This was ure the only caue of all the misfortunes that perecuted o innocent an affection: The aurance that Alcidalis had of Zelindas kindnes, made him live with more dicretion,
& more fear of dipleaing the Queen, then ever he waited on her Daughter oftner, & convert les with Zelinda, he who from her Childhood had been ever erious, began to be more and more o to ee and peak to the Prince with great Caution and repect, and do all things that might make their affections les upected; but this dicretion, as it did ever between Lovers, come too late, the Queen who could not be deceived, with much care, ecrecy and diligence, gave order for the executing a deigne which he had in hand, as thoe which are in a place with their enemies ecretly undermine, for the mot part fear leat of all the ruine they mut ink into, and live in ecurity whilt men dig Graves under their feet; o our Lovers not imagining what was contriving againt them, enjoyed a perfect Tranquility, and if they apprehended any michief from the Queen, they neither apprehended it o great, o uddain, nor in that dreadful manner it was to befall them. Four Months after the Queen came back from Catalonia, he took an occaion to
in the beginning of the Spring to return, giving no notice of any uch intention, till the day before. Alcidalis and Zelinda were o urpried, that they had carce leaure to take leave one of the other, as the Prince was expreing to her, the Grief he left her with. Sir, aid he, Remember you promied me, never to complain or fear the combination of the whole World againt you, whilt I was for you: Minds aured one of another, like Martyrs in the midt of all their Sufferings, have till their thoughts fixt together with joy, on their reward to come, we hall meet again, and even in abence, our Memories hall make our pat Satisfactions ever preent to us, and our imagination hall entertain us with thoe to come: At that word he took a Ring from her fair hand; and bad him keep it with her heart. Alcidalis received it with all the joy his own was capable of, and was almot in love with the ad occaion that drew o obliging a Dicoure from her; then taking another of the ame inetimable value, ince it came from him, he gave it her with
the ame words, at which they parted with as much Grief as ever they had met with Joy: Tears tole down both their Faces, which both trove to hid from each other, as ahamed of uch a vulgar mark of Sorrow in o Trancendant a concern. The Queen went away next Morning, and taying but one day at her own houe, he pretended to have received ome News from Barcellona, which obliged her to go thither, leaving her Daughter with a great part of her Train: She took only Zelinda with her, who imagined there was omewhat extraordinary in it; but was not able to comprehend the reaon; o that knowing not what to fear, he feared every thing: The Queen pent the remainder of that day in eeing the Town, and the magnificent reception that was made for her; the next morning he was told that a Veel bearing her own Name, which he had built not long ago, was newly come into the Port, there was then an hundred Veels in the Port of Barcellona, which o oon as the Queen appeared, aluted her
with all the Guns, o that for a while there was nothing to be een but Fire and Smoak, the Ships being hid with a Cloud of their own making, they oon made themelves heard in a ound of Trumpets and Howboys: The Muick and all the Naval Pompe, together with the ight of that Element, which at firt eies the Eyes and Minds of all the World with Admiration, could not in the leat divert Zelinda; her, heart preaged thoe ills at hand, he had o long foreeen. The Queen put her elf into a Boat, to go and ee this Veel, and took Zelinda with her and ome few Servants; She found in the Veel, the Captain and his Wife, with whom he hut her elf up a while, which extreamly increat the jealouies of Zelinda, he lookt toward Spain with Tears in her Eyes, and began to depair of eeing it again: An hour after, the Captain and his Wife came out of the Cabine, and told Zelinda, the Queen expected her there, her Blood traight Froze in her Veins, and he grew o Pale, that he eemed rather her own Ghot then her elf;
the Queen hutting the dore upon her, thus began. Though it be a long time Zelinda ince we lot both; you the bet Mother in the world, and I the bet Friend; Neither the affection that I had for her, nor the lat words he recommended you to my care, with hall ever be forgotten: And had thee former coniderations been wanting, your Beauty, your Wit, and Dicretion, would have ince obliged me to it. Having Bread you up o long, and having found all thee Qualities that gained her my affection, hineing in you with more Luter: I were unreaonable had I not the ame Friendhip for you, that I profet to her. Then ay I have done more for you then ever he askt of me, he only deired me to love you as her Daughter, and I have loved you like my own; my Daughter lot the Title of an only Child from the day your Mother dyed. Since when I have conidered you both as equally my own, and conequently none of your actions or concerns have been indifferent to me, o that you may imagine it is impoible but I mut have taken notice of that paion which your Beauty (though without
leave) has raied in the heart of Alcidalis: I have been no les then your elf in pain for the injury it might do you. You know how little aurance there is in the the words of men of his age and condition; both which gave him a licene to deceive and falifie his Promies: Be your own Judge, whether his affection can ever be any advantage to you, you ee how many reaons oppoe it, and hould it ever come into his power and yours, you are too jut, too grateful, to take him from the Daughter of one you are o much obliged to. I know your Vertue Zelinda, but as great as it is you cannot hinder the Prince from eeing you, nor the World from Talking of it; your Vertue may avoid the ill, but cannot ecape the noie; I know the prejudice uch reports are to thoe of your Sex, and particularly the dicontent they give thoe of your Scrupulous Vertue: I thought it then my duty to lead you out of this difficulty, and that it was now high time to fulfill the Promie I made your Mother. The Prince of Tarentum is Wie, Vertuous, and Valliant, one of the mot coniderable Princes in Italy; He has by his
Letters and Ambaadors, made addrees to me, that he might have you in Marriage; I would never acquaint you with particulars till all was ettled and the buines ripe for Execution. I hear he expects uddainly to lay at your Feet his Peron, and Dominions; the Captaine of this Veel left him fifteen days ago, and obliged himelf in as many more to bring you to him, according to my Orders, Diligence and Secrecy for ome reaons which I cannot yet let you know, are very important to this Affair, therefore you mut go away immediately, and without any Train. I doubt not but this your good nature finds ome trouble in this uddain parting, but though the Sea eparate us for a while, nothing hall divide our affections; and I hope one day to ee you with a Luter and Magnificence, which hall recompence the private condition you leave us in and ure you ought to be glad, you are returning into a Countrey where you hall find your Fortune, your Friends, and the place of your Birth. But although it were not your inclination, it is enough that I will have it o: Beides the power
of a Queen; I claim alo the interet of a Mother in you: Conent then willingly to a thing (which beide that it is a thing very jut) is alo no les neceary; in following readily what I counel you, and perhaps command you, you will hew that Modety that you owe to your elf, and a repect no les due to me: At thee words he embrac't her; pretending he would not take a formal leave of her, let it hould too much often both their hearts, he left the Cabin.

Sorrow, Rage, and Indignation, o overwhelmed the mind of Zelinda, that for a while he was neither able to peak nor move, o that he remained in the condition the Queen left here in Which yet was the happiet he found her elf in for many Months, ince the greatnes and uddainnes of her mifortune, took from her all ene of it for the time. All our faculties are o limited, that they are only capable of moderate Objects too much light blinds us, a great noie makes us deaf great Joys oppres our Senes. After having been without any ign of life for half an hour, her Spirits began to return,
and with them her Fear, her Love, and all the paions of a troubled Mind; Her life came back to her in uch a company that he hated it; her firt thought was that of throwing her elf at the Queens Feet, in hope to change her Cruel purpoe; but he was gone, and the Ship o far advanc't, that one could hardly ee the tops of Houes of Barcelona, he turned her eyes that way, and reflecting on what he left, and what he was going to: And having eriouly weighed them a while, he turned her elf towards thoe that accompanied her with a Countenance more cheerful and Serene then ordinary: and eeming to have received ome atisfaction from the conolation they gave her: See went to Bed, and entreated them to leave her to her Ret: Fear and hopes are the two contrary winds of Souls, which never ceae, and there is no tempet, whereof one or other of them is not the Caue: The preent is but a point, and would be inconiderable to us, if one or other of thee paions did not give us ome feeling of the future:
Zelinda thought that Fortune had plac't her below her own power of helping, or harming farther: And o was in that fatal Tranquility wherein men neither fear nor hope, but expect the end of their Misfortune, with that of their lives, In all thee Mieries, he had not that of trying everal remedies, which is commonly the greatet paine of the unfortunate. Having well conidered what he would do, and knowing it could not be long e're he hould be freed from her afflictions, he pat the night in thinking how Alcidalis would receive the News of her los: And though he was infinitly grieved to part with him, he had ome atisfaction when he thought of the eminent proof it, would give him of her love, and reolution. The Captain of the Veel (beides that he was then their charge) had a particular eteem of Zelinda having known her at Court; as oon as they thought he was awake they went into her Chamber, and askt her what he would eat, he anwered that not only he would not eat then, but that
he would never eat more; this reply amazed them extreamly; but they concluded he was relaped into her former Melancholly, and a little Time, a properer Remedy, then any dicoure. Three or four hours after, finding that he called no body, they returned, and employed all Prayers, and perwaions to make her receive a little Nourihment; to which he anwered only with a Sullen ilence, and a Beheaviour o cold, and o reolved, that he carce eemed to have heard them: They left her this econd time, but began to apprehend ome Tragical event of this trange reolution. The next night they came again with a Neece of theirs, who was of the ame age with Zelinda, and kneeling to her, begged her to have a care of her life, with as many Tears, and as much earnetnes, as if they had askt their own of her, but all in vain; o that they retired, and left her to her elf. Three dayes pat thus whilt neither Prayers, Tears, or Perwaions, could prevail with Zelinda to peak one word; but the fourth day thee good people
with their Neece, came to make their lat attempt: And deired her not to be her own Murderer, and commit a Cruelty upon a Peron o excellent, as even the rudet Barbarians would both pare and Worhip: Zelinda having hearkned a while to their Dicoure, fetcht a deep Sigh, and riing from her Seat, hewed her elf plain to them which made them the better perceive the extremity he was in; in the Beautifullet Face in the World, they beheld a frightful Image of dipair and approaching Death, and omewhat that gave at once horrour and pitty; having looked round upon them all, he thus broke the Silence, he o long had kept.
div.q:
My Friends, you ask of me a thing, that only you can give me, you would have me live, and I would willingly obey; but have reolved never to come alive upon the Shore of Italy, and here I wear it once more, to the Gods above, by Fire, and Light, and to thoe below by the Ghots of my Ancetors: My life is then no
longer in my power, it now depends on your carrying, or not carrying me to Italy; be not then my Murtherers, you to whoe care I was committed. The Duke of Tarentum expects me, he has never een me, you have here your Neece of my Age and Stature, and not unlike me in the Face; you may put her in my place, and o at once advance her Quality and Fortune in the World, and ave me from the greatet Misfortune I know how to fear; 'tis true you will deceive the Duke in giving him another then was promied him, but could you bring me to him in the condition, and weaknes I am now, he whom I would perwade you to give him, would much better reemble that Zelinda he has heard of. The Duke will ure be happier in a Wife that will receive, if not meet his love, then in the forc't Poeion of another, who upon erious conideration has preferred her Grave to his Bed. But 'tis not me he aims at, ince he never aw me, it is the Dutchy of Otrante that he deires, and I give it this minute to
your Neece, with the Quality and Name of Zelinda, and call to Witnes the ame Gods I have o lately Sworn by, that none hall ever know the contrary from me, and that I never will repent of it. The Queen I know commanded you to carry me where he expects me, but you will do her better ervice in obeying her Will, than her Words; an • can you think if he were here now and aw the condition I am now in and knew the reolution I have no • taken: That he had not rather •• me afe in any part of the World then to eed me dead into Italy; d •• he command you to put me alive •• dead into the hands of the Prince ••
Tarentum; do not you believe he d •
igned my Happines and Advancement in this Marriage, and that he w •• had o great a care of my Fortu •• would have a much greater care •• my Life: When I am dead and •• the World hall reproach the Que •• with this inhumane Cruelty, •• not he ay he was mot Innoce •• in that he did not know my Mi ••
my Averion to the Match, and lat of all my Deperate Reolution: May he not jutly lay the whole fault on you, but what need you give her any Account at all; This Veel is your own where ever Wind or Waves have paage you may go.
div.p: Then taking out a little Box the Queen had left her, where all the Jewels of her Mother were, he continued.
div.q:
Thee Jewels are of infinite Value, the Queen cannot make you a greater Preent; except he gives you Barcelona. Take them, and give me nothing in return, but my Life and Liberty; and ince Liberty it elf, is more then all the Riches of the World, I hall acknowledge my elf till your Debtor; too many would kill the Innocent Zelinda, for half the Wealth I offer you to ave her: I buy a good Virtuous Action of you, at a Price able to engage many men in the the mot Barbarous: If you make a cruple of diobeying the Queen, you
ought to have an horrour for the death of an Innocent; will you rather chooe to detroy one of her Friends, then to break one of her commands; If you are afraid of her dipleaure or wrong, you hould conider, that hortly Alcidalis will be greater in Arragon then he, who will eek you all over the World, and bring you to a evere account for my Life, and Peron: But if all thee reaons hould not prevaile, I conjure you by the Friendhip you have profet to me, by the compaion you hewed but now, by thee Tears, and all that is dear to you, to deliver me from this Ditraction I am in, your uddain reolution will double the Obligation, and incline me to believe, that you were dipoed to it more through your generous Pitty of my afflicted innocence, then any other conideration: But if neither my Prayers, nor Tears, nor Offers, can prevail with you: This Tongue that has pleaded my Caue o unuccesfully, hall never peak again, and death in a hort time will give me that Liberty which you refue.
div.p:
Then he hewed them all her Jewels, which Charmed their Eyes, as much as her Dicoures had done their Ears, o that they were no longer able to reit that double violence: The Captain was a Souldierly man, and very Brave, who had run through divers Fortunes without ever making his own: He thought now was the time or never, o that traight computing how many Veels he might et out with a good part of that Wealth he aw; immediatly all Zelinda had aid to him appeared unanwerable, he thought himelf oblidged in Honour to relieve o Lovely and Injured a Princes: Beides, that he might one day retore her to Alcidalis, and receive from him as great a recompence, as he had done for her. He was a great while without peaking, o that Zelinda fearing his Silence, proceeded from his irreolution, doubled her intreaties, till at lat he yielded, and vow'd to obey what ever he commanded: She engaged to go into a Monatery, and never to leave it without his conent: Zelinda was o overjoyed
at this deliverance from the Prince of Tarentum that he a while forgot he was alo eparated from Alcidalis; this atisfaction oon retored her to Health and Beauty; but they let her appear as little as poible; and their Neece Crimina was every day intructed to Peronate Zelinda; when he had her Leon perfect, they Landed her in Italy; though Zelinda aw all things go very well, and that the Captain and his Wife were very zealous to have this deign ucceed; yet her heart began to beat when he aw Land, and was extream impatient, till Crimina was ettled with the Duke, that he might be gone: Not to expoe the fale Zelinda at firt, to the eyes of too many People, under the pretence of ome mall Indipoition, they made her to be carryed in a Chair, into the very Pallace, and under the ame pretence avoided eeing much Company, till he had confirmed her elf in the Meen and Peron of a Princes; o that he let none ee her when he could well avoid it but the Duke; who though he did not find in her
that Prodigious Beauty that had made o much noie, was very well Satisfied with her, and attributed her Alteration partly to her Indipoition, partly to her Voyage, and allowed omewhat for the Extravagance of Report, which is ever in Extreams. The Captain and his Wife having received very coniderable Preents, took their leave of the Duke, and put to Sea, pretending an Impatience they had to give the Queen an account of their happy Voyage. Zelinda tayed all this while in the Veel, and when he aw the Captain and his Wife Aboard, pret them to Hoyt Saile, and hed as many Tears of Joy at her leaving Italy, as he had of Sorrow at her quitting Spain: But what avails it, the unhappy to ecape one Misfortune; or what Sanctuary is there for thee whom Fortune is reolved to Perecute; all the earth is ubject to her Empire, but the Sea eems to be particularly under her Dominion, it is there he excercies her Power mot Tyrannically; and mot Treacherouly, enriching her Favourites with the
Spoiles of the Indutrious: Yet as if there were nothing more to be feared, Zelinda thanked Heaven, and being on an Element the mot deceiptful of the four, among people he could expect nothing farther from, having nothing more to bribe them with. She imagined her elf as ecure as if he had been in a Pallace, and in the midt of her Friends: They made towards Sardignia, where the Captain deigned to leave Zelinda; with a Siter of his, till he could find an opportunity to retore her to Alcidalis; they had Sailed three dayes with a Fair Wind, when two hours before the Sun et, he upon the Watch, from the top of the Mat, cryed he aw three Sailes making towards them; Men live no where with o little ecurity, as upon that Element, The Water, Earth, Air, and Fire, are all Enemies of thoe that are at Sea; but Men mot of all, and there is nothing that one Veel apprehends o much, as the Meeting of another; not long after they looked again, and they aw the Tops of three Sailes, which eemed
not to be above three Leagues off; an hour after they came more in View, o that they knew them to be Pyrates. Our Captain commanded his men to Hoit all their Sailes and run for't: The next Morning as oon as it was broad day, they perceived the Pirates were aide of them, and within ix Miles, o that if they gained upon them in the Morning proportionably to what they had done in the Night before, they judged that by Noon they would be within Cannon-Shot; thoe that were in the Veel were a little apprehenive, the fearful took themelves to Crying and Howling, the mot reolved, to their Arms: And the mot reaonable, concluded, that neither the one nor other were to any great purpoe; Though the Captain had experience enough to know that he could not Defend himelf long, yet he choe rather to die like a man of Honour, then to yield and looe that Wealth he was o lately and o luckily poet of. In this Alarum and general confuion, Zelinda alone was not atoniht, and whilt others feared for
their Goods, and their Liberties, he to whom all thee things were indifferent, thought only for preerving her Honour: After having throughly conidered the danger he was in, and the remedies it was capable of; She hut her elf into her Chamber with the Captains Wife, where the firt thing he did, was to throw all her Ornaments into the Sea, leat they hould dicover her, then cutting off the Finet Haire in the World, he Wept a while in the conideration of what Fortune had reduced her to; but at lat he called for a Suit of the Clothes of the Captains, and Diguied her elf and Sex. In the mean time the three Veels which they knew belonged to the Coat of Africa, came within Cannon-Shot of them, and Dicharged a Gun, to ee if they would Strike Saile, but finding they did not, but pretended to defend themelves, when they came within convenient ditance they gave them a Broad-Side: thoe of the Veel did the ame, but with a very different ucces for doing no harm at all to the Enemies,
they had their Mat and two of their Sailes Shot in pieces, their Veel extreamly Shattered, and many of the Souldiers killed; at this noie Zelinda came out of her Chamber, and put her elf among the foremot, hoping that he hould by that means either be killed the ooner, or diguie her elf the better, the Combate was o unequal that it was impoibie it hould lat long, and all the reitance they were able to make, could not hinder the Pirates from Boarding the Veel; where after they had killed ten or twelve of the mot Reolute, and amongt the ret the Captain, the Seamen threw down their Arms, and yeilded to Mercy The Captain of thee Veels was of the Kingdom of Barca, the people of it are very Barbarous, they drive no Trade at all, what we call Robbing, they call Gaining from the Enemy, and whatever they purchae with their Blood, they count till the bravelier, and mot Honetly gotten; and would be ahamed of any other Title to it. This man being the mot powerful in his Country,
Valliant and Skilfull in Sea Affairs, was a long time the Terrour of all the Coats of Greece and Italy, he had Mercy, and Generoity more then his Country, or indeed his Profeion allowed of, naturally and without knowing they were Vertues: As there are in the North, ome Veins of Gold as perfect as thoe in the Indies, though not in o great quantity. So nature in all Climates does produce now and than an extraordinary Genius, which he intructs and cultivates her elf, and indues with all imaginable perfection without help of Art. As Orcantes (for o this Pyrate was called) was looking over his Captives and the Prize he had gotten. The Majety and Beauty that hined in Zelindas Face, compelled him to ask her who he was, he anwered he was a Spaniard, and her name was Zelidan, Nephew to the Captain of that Veel, he had taken, that he wiht her elf with him, and eteemed him happy to have preerved his Liberty with the los of his Life: She aid this with a meen worthy of a better
Fortune, and with an aurance more uual in the Conquerours then the vanquiht, her Contancy, her Courage, prevailed more on the Generous Dipoition of the Captain, then all the mean Submiion of the ret, he was charmed with the Greatnes of her Mind, and Beauty of her Peron, and deired her to be of good Courage, ince he was fallen into the hands of one, who made Slaves of none but uch as deerved to be o. That for himelf he ought Glory more then Gain upon the Sea, and took more pleaure to give Liberty, then to make Slaves. That he left the ret of the Prize to his Souldiers, and deired only Zelidan for himelf, and that the firt brave Action they were in, hould be his Ranome. And Sir, aid he, If the advantages of your Mind, anwer thoe of your Peron, I hall oon be more a Captive to your Worth, then you are to my Arms. Zelinda, who expected nothing of this nature from a Barbarian, and a Pyrate, was almot as much amazed as he was pleaed; and the los of Liberty, as a Slave to Orantes,
was o much more upportable then it would have been to her as Wife to the Prince of Tarentum, that he began to bear it with ome ort of atisfaction. She thought there was no misfortune but to be given to another, nor no Happines but to be Married to Alcidalis: All things ele were indifferent to her. And o her great Soul worthy of the Empire of the World, ubmitted to her preent condition with les concern then the meanet Seaman that was taken with her. But Zelidan for o we mut hereafter call her, beides that Heaven had given her all Advantagious Qualities, both of Mind and Body, was indued with all thoe Graces, which almot inenibly create Love & Repect, born to command and not to obey: She oon got the acendant over her new Mater, the Slaves, Souldiers, Seamen, all loved her o well, that he Governed abolutely, in the Veel where he was Prioner; eeing the kindnes Orantes had for her, he judged that it would turn to Love, if once he were dicovered; and then his inclination
(which ele would be of great advantage to her) would be infallibly her ruine She took all the care imaginable to conceal her elf continually exerciing her Courage, and all thee Qualities that her Sex is leat capable of. They pat all that Summer without ever landing, but to take in Freh-Water, in which time the new Zelidan ignalized himelf on all occaions: There was no Veel taken where he was not the firt Aboard o that the Pirate found no difficulty to pay him the full eteem and friendhip he had promied: The Winter coming on, and the Sea growing fuller of fears, then hopes even for Pyrates themelves, they laid up their Veel in the firt Port of Barca: Orantes gave Zelidan his Liberty with a great many Complements, and profeions of perpetual Friendhip: He deired to bring him to Court, aying he would hew the King the Richet Prize he ever took upon the Sea. In the mean while Alcidalis who was informed of the Queens whole proceeding, believed Zelinda in the Arms of the Prince of
Tarentum, and thought her capable though not of loving, yet of uffering another, the generous reolution of tarving her elf to death, which Zelinda was ready to have executed, Alcidalis was not able to imagine: But after he had given ome time to a helples and a mot peechles orrow, he lot all fear, all repect, together with his hope, and had no other though but that of Revenging himelf immediately upon the Queen, or of forcing Zelinda from the Arms of the Prince of Tarentum. But at lat his Body being unequal to the violent Agitations of his Mind, he fell into a Feavour, accompanied with uch Raving Fits, as all that knew their true caue, had reaon to believe he would never outlive them; he was in a hort time without any trength, and which was happiet for him without any thought at all: thus Fortune can mock at all our Purpoes, and confine him a whole Month to his Chamber; Who threatned traight to earch the whole World for Zelinda. A Feavour, Love, and Jealouy, which are
certainly the greatet ills of Mind and Body, raged at once in Alcidalis, every one of them with their mot deperate Circumtances: So that each eemed incurable and altogether unupportable: But at length contrary to all expectation he recovered, but with his Health, his Grief, his Love, and all cares returned; o that without taying till he was perfectly recovered, or making any one acquainted with his deigne, he tole out of Saragoa, and going a by way to the Kingdom of Valentia, he embarqued at the nearet Port, and pat over into Italy: Where he hoped to ee Zelinda, which expectation was all the Happines he was capable of in her abence; The fale Zelinda had better Fortune then the true one, and her deignes better ucces, he had, as oberved, a moderate Beauty, and that kind of undertanding that gives us cunning and ubtility for the Affairs of the World, eeing what a dangerous buines he had undertaken, he endeavoured all he could to gaine the Prince her Husbands Heart, and o fortifie her elf
againt all accidents: He was of thoe years wherein men begin to feel the approaches of Old Age, and to be omewhat les confident of themelves, and where the mot reaonable and bet deerving cannot hope to be loved by Women, but out of gratitude or duty: So that the Beauty, Conduct, and Kindnes, of his Young Wife, gained him intirely: As we are never o fond of Flowers, as in the beginning of the Spring, or towards the end of Autumne; the firt for their Novelty, and the others becaue we think we hall ee them no more: So the pleaures of love are at no time o dear to us, as in the buginning of our Youth, and the approaches of our Age: It is o great and unexpected a Happines for an Old Man to be loved, that there is no folly they are not capable of in that condition, but the knowledge they have of themelves, carce uffers them ever to be firmly perwaded of it. The Duke was no ooner in love, but he became Jealous; That paion which in other Countries is an accidental effect of love, is there ineperable
from it they conclude there cannot be a great deire, without a great fear. Love and Jealouy are Twins with them, and ever born together. Were it then the exces of kindnes, the Air of his Countrey, or his own natural ditrut, or that he had heard omewhat concerning Alcidalis, that had caued that effect; his Jealouy arrived to that height, that he never thought her afe but when he was with him, and even then had carce patience he hould be een by any eyes but his own. She who for another reaon cared not to be een much, eaily complied with his Humour, and told him he loved all the effects of his Paion equally, that his very fears were agreeable to her ince they were marks of his Love: That her greatet content was to procure his, that in having him, he thought he had all the World, and cared not if he was hut up for ever on thee Tearms. He receives thee offers of hers with great joy, and made ue of the Liberty he gave him to take away all hers, o that cutting off dayly omwhat of her Attendants, and of a
great Pallace, which before he had the freedom of, he reduced her to four or five Rooms, and a few neceary Servants, as the Duke gave her many marks of his Jealouy, he alo gave her ome of his Love. And trove to make her Prion as agreeable to her as poible, there was no part of the World that did not contribute its greatet varieties to her Cloets. Art and nature eemed to trive which hould mot adorne her Retirement. And he aw all things he could wih, but men, and thoe he aw only out her Windows. The Duke bought the Lutiet and Handomet Slaves that could be found which (to divert the Malancholy which mut needs attend uch a olitude) he caued to be taught to Fence, Ride, run at the Ring, and all the exercies of the Nobility, by the bet Maters of Italy; thee were called the Slaves of the Dutches, thrice a Week they were brought into a Court all trewed with Sand, where they did all their Exercies: The Duke had two deigns in this, one of diverting his Dutches, and the other of
making her depie all men; by letting her ee in Slaves, the ame Qualities which are admired in people of the highet Birth, and mot advantagious Education. Alcidalis at his coming into Italy, was informed of all this, and judged that no Quality would o oon introduce him, as that of a Slave to the Dutches; he communicated his deigns to his Gentleman, who had always attended him; who Diguiing himelf like a Merchant, went to the Officers that had the Government of the Slaves, and expoed to ale Alcidalis; who having all the Qualities neceary in a very eminent degree; was oon Bought, and o one of the greatet and mot accompliht men in the World, became a Slave: A while he was fain to learn of them he might have taught and eeming to learn every day omewhat of his exercies; he in a hort time o advanced, that he was admired of all the World; if he were challenged to run, Wretle, Fence, or Ride, he was o contantly uccesful, that at lat he eemed but to be invited to o many Victories:
There was no Prize that any one, or number of his Companions, durt dipute with him: Yet among all the commendations he obtained, he felt a ecret hame in himelf, that his Victories were gained only over a few Slaves, for he had a heart as Generous as that Prince, who corned to Run with any but Kings, though he did all things with an incomparable Grace, it was with o much neglect and contempt of what he was about, that it was no hard matter to ee his thoughts were omewhere ele: When ever he entered the Lits, for the Divertiement of the Dutches, he came the firt, and went away the lat; In all his exercies he had his Eyes and Heart fixt upon the Window, he thought he tood at. For the Jealous Duke had o contrived it; that he could ee without being een: What Mitakes and Errors are not men capable of, the mot Faithful Lover upon earth adores now a Beauty he has never een, Sighs before her, and gives her at his eyes his heart: And being born a Slave to Zelinda, has blindly
old himelf to another: Alcidalis who had been remarkable amongt the mot accompliht Princes, was eaily o among thee Slaves. The firt day he aw him, his Beauty, and the Graces that accompanied all his Actions, attracted the eyes of the Dutches; afterward he gained her eteem, and then her admiration; and having conidered how throughly he thought he aw in his Mine and Courage, omewhat worthy of a Nobler detiny, and much above his preent Fortune: She took notice how fixtly he looked up at her Window, of the Palenes and Sadnes of his Face, which all the applaues continually given him were never able to change for a Minute: All this together gave her at firt Pity, then Curioity, and at lat Love.

One Night as this Illutrious Slave went out of the Palace of the Duke, in a dark Paage he felt himelf pulled by one, whom by that light he could only perceive to be a Woman; who taking him aide, aid, Clariantes,
