(for that was the name he choe to be called by in this Diguie) If you are as truly Brave as you appear, come to morrow morning at two a Clock to the foot of the Greek-Tower, there you hall be put in a way of being the Happiet man living: She aid this in great hate, and left him, without taying for his anwer. But this was enough to et his Thoughts a work: Since Fortune began to perecute his love, this eemed to him the firt Moment he began to remit of her uual Rigour; he made no quetion but this Meage came from Zelinda, ince to make him Happy was in the power of none but her: Yet whether it be that men o extraordinary hold ome little intelligence with their detiny, or that the unfortunate entertain hope but Coldly, which has o oft deceiv'd them: he durt not be confident of his good Fortune, but expected the hour he had aigned him, ucceively agitated by Impatience, Hope, and Fear. The time o much longed for being come, as oon as it was dark he came to the foot of
the Tower, which was an old Building which entered ome fifty Foot into the Sea; Alcidalis came in a mall Fiher Boat, which having fatned to the Wall, he attended the ucces of his Adventure an hour before any body came to him: His Mind all the while no les tos'd between Hope and Fear, then the mall Veel he was in by the Waves of the Sea: Paions which though they are very contrary, are very often together; the Wind was o high, that there was mall hope the Rope that held the Boat would endure much longer, o that every Minute he imagined it would break; at lat, as he began to depair of his expected Happines, and entertain the dimalet thoughts the Night, the Sea, and riing Storm could furnih him with; he heard a noie from the top of the Tower, which he anwered to, and immediatly omthing fell into his Boat, which he oon perceived to be a Ladder of Rope: Alcidalis then gave himelf entirely into the Arms of a deceitful hope, and was confident he hould once more behold his unfortunate
Zelinda: which made him light all dangers, and run up the Ladder as fat as he could have done the eaiet Stairs in the World; when he was at the top, he found a Window open, and a Woman who gave him her Hand, and without aying any thing, brought him through a great many turnings into a Cloet, the Richliet Furniht that ever he had een, lighted with three Lamps of Gold: He perceived then he was the ame Woman had poke to him before in the dark Paage; then putting all things together, he concluded he came from Zelinda, and had now no fear but that of not taying long enough with her: He had a thouand everal and ome contrary Paions at once in his Mind, which cannot be repreented on Paper, ince the Soul of man, and amongt them, only the Lovers, is capable of uch confuion: He was for an hour in the tillet Silence imaginable, but at lat he heard, as he thought, the tread of a Woman, and the noie of a Key, to which turning his Head about, he aw a Door open, and the
ame peron enter who gave him her hand at the Window; who Smiling upon him, aid, Clariantes, I do not doubt but you will pardon me for having made you wait thus long, and confes the Honour you are going to receive, an abundant recompence for all you have uffered. The Prince thanked her; and deired he would inform him a little what this Honour was he meant; She paued a while, and then replyed, Were I not by the Greatnes of your Meen and Courage, ufficiently aured of that of your Mind, I hould not venture to let you know your good Fortune thus at once, let exces of joy hould overpower your Spirits; but it is to be uppoed a man of your Merit can never be urprized at his good Fortune, whatever it be; know then, that you are now in Zelinda's Cloet, and hall immediatly be brought into her Chamber; the Dutches has taken notice of your good Qualities, and finding nothing amis in you but your Fortune, is reolved to better that her elf; and to that end deires your acquaintance: On your part ee you make good ue of this occaion, and hew as much Dicretion
and Conduct hereafter, as you have hitherto hewn Courage and Generoity. Having aid this, he led him into the Dutchees Chamber. How trangely are our Minds wrought upon? Alcidalis, whom death it elf would not have dicompoed, trembles in a place where he knew there were none but Women; that heart which would have encountered a world of Enemies without fear, melts at the imaginary approach of the only peron upon earth he loves, and knows himelf to be beloved by: The Chamber had jut the light that uch affairs required, which was not much; the hame and diorder of a Young woman unpractis'd in the Thefts of Love, made her conceal her elf o much, that had Alcidalis been les prepoet then indeed he was, he could not eaily have found his mitake: He immediately fell upon his Knees to her, and after a few words confuedly uttered, and wore followed, he topt in the middle of his Dicoure; Amazement, Joy, and Love eied him o in an intant, that half beide-himelf he let fall his head upon
the Bed of the young Princes, who lifting it up with her hand, brought him a little to himelf; but a conciounes of his diorder kept him till in it, o that he could only ay at lat,
div.q: Zelinda, Heaven has had ome pity on the unhappy Alcidalis, and once before I die given me a ight of thoe perfections I would have dyed to have een; my love is till the ame, and I am not the les yours for your being anothers; the Tyranny of Fate may force our Perons out of our own dipoal, but hearts are given by themelves alone, and ure what is unjutly taken, we jutly may recover.
div.p:
Here his Sighs interrupted his Dicoute, and as he would have continued it, they heard a great noie in the Palace, which he that was intruted came out of Breath to tell them it was the Duke, and that he was already on the Dutches Side: Who, good man, far from thinking what had happened, had deigned to pend two
or three days in Hunting; but whether it were Love, or Jealouie, or that he thought, that for being les expected he hould be the more welcome to the Dutches; he returned the very day, and the firt thing he did, came to viit her. I hate him for coming o uneaonably; for I would fain have een what reply he would have found to a Dicoure he o little comprehended, and les expected; and had I made the Story, Alcidalis hould have made him—what the Dutches pleaed: But as things were, there was no taying any longer, and the Lady that brought him, in all hate conducted him to the ame Window he came in it. Seeing and deteting this lat Treachery of Fortune, he had more mind to precipitate himelf, then to make ue of his Ladder of Ropes, and had done it, but for the hope of Climing up by it another time. The weetnes of that thought perwaded him to live a little longer, but with many rah Vows and deep Imprecations, not to urvive uch another Jilting trick; and brought him afe,
and unoberved to his Lodging; for the Dukes unexpected arrival had raied all from leep, and put the Court in uch Confuion, that they ran againt each other as if it had been at blind-mans-Buffe: (a Recreation much ued at Courts in that Age, and not yet wholly dieteem'd.) To ave the trouble of making doleful Speeches and avoid the danger of peaking untruths, or wore then he did, I will not preume to relate exactly how often Alcidalis Sighed, Tumbled, and Rouled in his Bed, omtimes Rayling at, and ometimes wheadling Fortune; or whether he tore his lovely Hair, which in a thouand Curls adorned his preading Shoulders; for he being then under the qualification of a Slave, had no attending Equire to hear and dicover his Soliloquies. But let the ingenious Reader imagine, after a long and paionate Courthip of o Beautiful a Lady as Zelinda, if he was Kneeling by her Bed, (the Altar of Love) preing her oft Palm, laying his amorous head on her panting Breat, in the height of extaie, jut
at the Minute of fruition, (for doubtles they had been naught together, if the Dukes coming had not prevented them) how it would tir him to be diappointed: And then let him pleae his fancy with Speeches uitable to his own Humour.—Here ome Romantick Zealots may perhaps accue me of a gros mitake, in uppoing a Prince o ubllmely Virtuous as Alcidalis is Characteriz'd, could be guilty of the common Failings of meaner perons: But I refer my elf to the Impartial Judgement of this ripe-witted Age, whether that Lover is not mot perfect, whoe Paion has no Limits (maugre the Cruel examples of Amadis de Gaul, that flower of Chivalry, and all the Rabble of obolete Heroes) but in peruance of its deign, which is enjoyment one way or other, whatever is pretended to the contrary; tramples all danger, or reaon under Foot; I'le believe it granted, and proceed to my Story.—The ame exces of kindnes, or Jealouie rather, which hurried the Old Duke from his Countrey diverions, hatened him to
the Chamber of his Trembling Dutches; who received him with mot extraordinary marks of unuual Tendernes, the better to palliate her Errour; often renewing her trict Embraces, with a melting voice, he aid,
div.q: My Dearet Lord! The only joy of my Life! Are you well? Are you in my Arms? Oh peak! and confirm me that I am not yet in a Dream—

No, Dear Madam! anwered the over joyed Duke, it is no Dream; or if it be, it is o ravihing to me, that I could be contented it hould never end: But what, my dear Zelinda, has o much dicompoed you? Your heart pants and truggles, as if it were weary of its Seat, and ought for helter in my Breat—

Oh Sir, he replyed, receive it kindly then! and let it ever dwell there, that it may no more be frighted with your abence. Your coming wakened me from a dreadful Dream; a great
Buck, me-thought, aaulted you in a dark Thicket, and was jut ready to goar your Majetick forehead with his Horns; Ha! Horns, cryed the Duke, (tarting as if his evil Genius had appeared) Heaven avert the Omen! If your preence had not diturbed my buie Fancy, certainly the Dream had gone one, ays he, and I had dyed with apprehenion—

Be comforted, Madam! ays the recollected Duke, Dreams are but faint reflections of thoe lat thoughts, which imployed the imagination when leep urprized the Active Senes; o when the Glorious Sun forakes our Hemiphear, a Roie glimmering lighr till guilds the Clouds.
Ah Sir! I will never conent that you hall leave my Arms, cryed the paionate Dutches, for if your precious life hould be detroyed, how wretched would the unfortunate Zelinda be!
div.p:
Repeating her Carees with uch
exquiite Artifice, and eeming Fondnes, that the Duke, believing himelf mot egregiouly Happy in a Kind and Faithful Spoue, when her heart was all that time inventing new Cures for him, committed all his cares to a ound leep; which Age, and a little forc'd exercie to retaliate his Ladies kindnes, oon brought upon him.

The next day was olemniz'd with more then uual Sports, where Alcidalis, welled with joyful hopes, performed uch extravagant Deeds of Agility and Strength, as I dare not particularize, let the incredulous Reader hould ditrut the truth of all the ret. The Duke unable to make good returns of Love two nights together, hut up his Exchequer, and as an uncivil Debtor that cannot Pay, avoids the ight of his obliging Creditor; he tole away as abruptly to his Country-Houe in the Evening, as he had come from thence the Night-before; leaving a Letter to inform and comfort the poor Dutches, with plentifull aurances of a peedy return;
adding, that he feared to bid her Farewell, let her Grief hould betray him to a weaknes misbecoming a Prince. She had oberved his cloe manner of retiring, and gladly gave him opportunity to Cheat himelf, while he thought to deceive her: but could not read his Conolatory Epitle, without downright Laughing—Old Age, Flannell, and Brandy, aid he, farewell! and immediately calling Florella, (for that was the Lady of her intrigue) ent her to Clariantes; concealing till from her, that it was the Prince Aleidalis, (whoe Name and Actions the Court was well acquainted with) and reolving to continue his mitake of her for the true Zelinda; ordered, that when he came, there hould be no light at all in her Chamber. Florella found him walking where he had received the former Summons, and failed not to deliver the econd Challenge; nor he to repair immediatly to the place appointed. Now Fortune eemed to fix her unteady Wheel; Smooth and Gentle, as a Frozen River, did the
Sea appear; and the amicable Moon, an indulgent cheriher of all Exploits of Love and Art, (like a well-wihing Procurer with a dark Lanthorn) from behind a able Cloud, diplayed jut light enough to lead him on, and not betray him. Swift as a ealed Dove, and as blind too with his Paion, he mounted to his Heaven, the Window, and in one moment more protrated himelf at the Shrine, the Bed of his Saint. Like a gay plum'd Phoenix, wrapped in perfumes, and languihing in Flames of Love, he lay; yet trembled like a new yean'd Lamb upon a heet of Snow, with eagernes of fierce deire. After his firt aault of Kies on her melting Hand, his Tongue got liberty to cry, Ye Gods! do I again behold the fair Zelinda? (a very pertinent Quetion, for it is to be remembred there was no Light) then overcome with extaies of joy, his head unk gently on her downy Breats, which proudly welled to welcom o deired a Guet, and meet his burning Kies; while with her tender Arrms, more White then Alpine Snow, he
kindly preed him cloer! Oh my ador'd Zelinda, (he panting cryed) to which he Ecchoed oftly with a Sigh, Oh my much loved Alcidalis! I had been too happy had I been only thine.—Here their Speech was Smothered with reiterated Kies and Embraces, till urged by opportunity, and timulated with greatnes of delight, with a repective Boldnes he continued—Why was the unfortunate Alcidalis permitted to ee uch dazling Glories, and hope for uch unexpreible blis, as Gods would quit again their Heaven for,—and not—En—j—! There with a Balmy Kis, he put a period to his Words; and with a pretty kind of obliging violence, he checked his wandring hands, while he purued his purpoe thus—If my adored Princes thinks my Sufferings yet too inconiderable to merit her eteem, if cuitting the powerful Charms of approaching Soveraignty, and foraking an indulgent dying Father, to wear the depicable Garb, and do the mean Offices of Common Slavery, deerve no Pity; invent
new Chains, Tortures, Deaths, and ee how readily I will imbrace them for Zelinda's ake—Too much, too much already, replyed the cunning yielding Dutches, has my beloved Prince endured—But—But!—But what! cryed the impatient Alcidalis—But you are anothers, you perhaps would ay: Ah Madam! were you not firt mine? were you not Baely, Treacherouly Ravihed from my Arms? And if a Thief has Robbed me, han't I eize my Treaure where I find it?—Concluding with a cloe imbrace,—Go, ye are an unkind naughty man, aid he—and I wont love—you indeed—if—you offer—Sighing, and gently triving to defend, what he had rather have dyed then keep—What, oh powerful opportunity! may not be effected by thy aitance? How weet a recompence did the mitaken Alcidalis think he had, for all his pains! and what a full revenge on Fortune for her Jilting Tricks, while he lay dying in the Arms of his uppoed Deity!—But oh the hortnes, and uncertainty of humane felicity! Who would not
think the tired Duke now taking large Arrears of leep, for his lat nights Diturbance! Who would believe, he hould o oon a econd time molet thee Lovers! Yet o it was; for in the height of all their Blis, Florella almot Breathles with her hate, ruhed in; cating back uch frightfull Looks, as if ome ghatiy Phantam had purued her; and by the Blazing light of a great Wax Taper which he brought, dicovered to the urpried Alcidalis, the fale Zelinda; and e're he could dicharge his Senes, from the Amazement that object raied, he increaed it by crying out, The Duke! The Duke was privately returned, and jut entered the Palace: which truth their ears immediatly confirmed, by the haty Footteps which they heard.—The Dutches, Pale and Trembling, had not power to peak, but with up-lifted Hands and Eyes, eemed to implore the aitance of Alcidalis; while Florella, whoe Senes were more at liberty, threw a looe Robe and Head-Tyre of the Dutchees on Alcidalis, hiding
his Face as much as the Dres would permit. Scarce was this done, when the Duke entered, claped him in his Arms, and pake the kindet things a doting Husband could invent, to oblige the bet Wife in the World: To which he dar'd make no reply; but Florella freed him from that trouble, telling the Duke, a uddain Tooth-ach, got by a cold he took the preceding night, made peaking extreamly troubleome; and welled her Face o, he dared not expoe it to the Air, let it increaed her Malady. Alcidalis took the hint, and began to Groan o Lamentably, it put his Grace into uch mortal apprehenions of her danger, that it was hard to judge who was in the greatet perplexity, He, the Prince, or the Dutches, who lay quaking under the Bed-Cloathes, like a Child frighted with the Tale of Raw head and bloody Bones. Death was the leat punihment the Lovers could expect, if they were dicovered. A hundred times did Alcidalis reolve to force his Paage over the Dukes feeble Body: But the conideration of the
Dutchees danger, as a Woman in ditres, though her impoture had much incened him, diverted all thoe thoughts to a Generous reolution of freeing her, or haring in her detiny. Thus Affairs tood, when Fortune eemed weary of tormenting them, and gave ome propect of hope, for the Uxorious Duke would himelf be the Meenger to call the Phyitians; which gave all hopes of etting things right 'ere he returned; but their Joy vanihed like a wift reflection of the Sun cat from a moving Looking-Glae; for the blind Quean, whoe ole delight conits in Tantalizing thoe that trut her, thrut them the next Minuit on the very brink of Ruine. The Duke unable to leave his Dear Zelinda without a Kis, found a trange unuual Roughnes on his Chin, and urpried with a udden fit of Jealouie, urveying him the ame intant from Head to Foot, imagined his dimenions ix times as big as his Zelinda's (for Paion blinds the Undertanding, as ome Dieaes cheat the Sight) and rending off the Head-Dres,
aw not only a man, but his Slave Clariantes, whoe extraordinary valour had made him worthy of his particular knowledge.—Immediatly running out, with loud Exclamations of Treaon, Treaon! the Guard repaired to his aid; when his back was turned, you may think Alcidalis was not idle, but cating off that faetal Robe, with a bravery of Spirit which never forook him, he prepared, though unarmed, to dipute his Life But e're he went, turning to the Dutches who was almot drowned in Tears, Madam, (ays he) if extravagancy of Paion, had not wholly eized my Reaon with my Senes, your Deportment, o contrary to her trict and potles Virtue, had aured me you were not the ncomparable Zelinda; but if you give me not ome account of that excellent Princes, by all the Gods I wear! to unvail your impoture, and expoe you to the jut Cruelty of the deluded Duke, though my death accompany your Infamy.—Ah Sir, (aid the deplorable Dutches) can you with uch extream rigour
pay my exces of Love? ingrateful man! the too happy Zelinda (ince o eteemed by you) lives in the Ile of Sardignia; it was to ave her life, I conented to become a Dutches—'Tis not, Cruel Prince! to the care of my own afety you owe for this dicovery, for with your elf, you take from me all deire to live: But to preerve your Life, (notwithtanding all your unkind contempt) ten thouand times dearer to me then my own. I once more tell you, your too happy Zelinda lives yet in Sardignia; in obedience to her own deire, attended thither by my Father. Shortnes of time forbids to tell you more: Now leave me to the everity of an incened Jealous Husband; but when you think of my failing, remember the Caue, and pity me.—Here the noie of the Dukes return tayed her Speech. Alcidalis had dyed in her defence, o graceful, and o moving was her grief, but hopes of eeing the true Zelinda banihed all other entiments. With Courage, even to rahnes, he cat himelf amidt
the Guard, and got afely off; for their too much hat, (the Mortal enemy of mot deigns) brought the Guard <> with o little light, that in the Confuion it was not difficult to pas without being dicerned. The inraged Duke entring, found his Dutches tanding in that very Dres and Poture he left Clariantes, only the Head-Tyre he had diordered, was again put on, and by the advice of Florella (who was old excellent at udden Shifts) he was o placed. Strait he cryes out to his Guard, There! There behold the audacious Traytor! take him, eize him, away with him to Tortures; let him be 100 Years dying. The Guard eeing none but the Dutches, like Statues tood without motion; The Duke tormed, Vowed all were in the Plot, & hould dye together; but firt that Villain Clariantes: Andrunning at the Dutches with his Drawn Sword, had certainly killed her, if Florella's hriek at his firt motion, had not made her tart aide. Yet he ecaped not without a Wound in her Side, which together with her fright, cat her on
the Bed in a woun: and by the falling off of her Head-Tyre, hewed the Duke what he had done.—He did not (as ome would expect) earch round the Chamber, and the Palace for Clariantes, but wholly ubmitted to his Uxorious Love; which like an impetuous Tyde, bare down his Anger, Faith, and Reaon; eeing his dear Dutches Bleeding, and as he thought breathing out her Soul by his accured hand, he threw himelf at her Feet, beat his Head againt the Ground, tore his Hair, and rooted up his Comely Beard (hold! let me not lye neither, perhaps Beards were as much out of Fahion then, as now, and conequently he wore none; I would not have Poterity impoed upon in matters of uch weight; truth will go through the World.) But I am ure he called himelf a thouand thick culled Ophes, Jealous Cox-combs, Villains, Murtherers, and turning to his Guard, begged them to Dipatch him, for he was a Tyrant, not worthy to live but among Beats; from intreaties he proceeded to commands,
and threats; but eeing them revere their Faces, and hang their Heads at his trange Propoition. Why, aid he, will you be cruel to your Prince? and deny him the only favour he ever begged from you, or that you can grant? I have mot inhumanely pierced my own oul, what afety can you hope from me? My hearts blood tains the Floor, and I can gaze upon't without dying; can you expect Jutice from uch a Monter? Gods! Why do I dec •• d to Petition o poorly, for what is in my power. Oh my Zelinda! the Blooms that enriched the early Spring, and with their fragrant eent perfum'd the gentle Southern Wind, were not o weet, nor half o Beautiful as thee: 'twould undoe the vat nivere to purchae o rich a Jewel as I have rahly thrown away—What ean my hated Carkae, this dull Clod of earth do in the World, when my Sun that gave it warmth, and life, lyes here Ecliped? Fool! Fool! Fool! that I am—Then he cat himelf again on her Body, and triving in vain to find ome igns of life, cryed out, Zelinda! Zelinda! She's gone;—for ever, for ever gone.—if
thy injured oul is yet hovering in the ambient Air, as ure it is loth to go far from o rich, o beautiful a Cabinet, let it behold the Sacrifice I offer for its Peace.—Starting up, he endeavoured to cat himelf on his Sword, but was prevented, & by the Phyitians and Chyrurtgeons who were then arrived, the Dutches was recovered from her woun: and her life aured, if no new accidenr prevented their care.—The Duke begged a thouand pardons for his folly, and tirred not from her Bed till he was Cured;—binding himelf with many vows, never to be Jealous again; nor did I ever hear of any farther difference between them; therefore I will leave them, with the ame farewell people give their departed Friend, who dyed with a Lord have mercy upon me in his Mouth, (though he lived impiouly) doubtles they are Happy.—

Oh Woman! Woman! thou dark abye of Subtilty; 'tis eaier to trace a wandring Swallow through the pathles Air, then to explicate the
crafty wyndings of thy Love, or Malice: Thy wift excues, and evaions, till like the Hydra's Heads increae: As Wizzards, in a moment y'are transformed to various Shapes, and when the injur'd Friend, or Husband, thinks to cruh a Serpent that has poioned all his Health and Peace, trait in the form of a Dove-like innocence you Baffle and Betray his jutet Rage. Angels would emulate the perfect Glory, and the Blet etate of man, were he not ubject to the ubtil Snares of your frail deceiving Sex

The Reader ought to pardon this Satyrick excurion to the Author, who has been more Injured by Woman, then e're the Duke or Alcidalis was.—That Prince, it may be concluded, oon found his Gentleman which lay incognito receive his commands; and taking his Jewels, repaired immediatly to the Sea ide, where a Ship being jut ready to leave the Port, (for that mut never be wanting to a Hero upon the Ramble) without asking whither he was
Bound, they went Aboard, and oon lot ight of that unfortunate Coat. With a properous Wind let them proceed, while we return to the ditreed real Zelinda, whom we unkindly left in mans Habit, under the name of Zelidan, in a trange place, at Barcha in Africa. By the favourable aitance of that ame generous Pyrate Orcantes, that gave her liberty, he obtained a Paage for Spain; and without meeting any extraordinary adventure, afely landed at the ame Port of Barcelona, from whence he had been forced away by the contriving Jealous Queen.—The ight of that Fatal place, preenting all pat Fortune frehly to her Memory, oppreed her Breat with Sighs; which Tempet was allay'd by a hower of Chrytal drops from her fair Eyes; Ah Alcidalis, aid he, if you do till preerve your vowed affection for the faithful Zelinda, what reaon will he have to glory in her Sufferings? Here he paued a while, pleaing her elf with that delightful thought; but on a udden breaking ilence, he went
on;—No! wretched Zelinda, no! never hope uch Bleings were ordained for thee; doubtles the Authority of a King, and Father, managed by the ininuating artifice of the Prudent deigning Queen, the interet of State, and the Beauties of the too charming Princes, to which adde his belief of my being Married to the Prince of Tarentum, have prevailed, and he is now for ever chained to the imbrace of that fortunate Princes.—Die! die Zelinda! let not the imperious Queen inult ore thy Ditres. Already was her hand upon her Sword, when Heaven, that never quite forakes the Virtuous, inpired her with more reaonable thoughts—That death was the extremet refuge of the mierable; and might afely be deferred as a remedy always in her power, ince no earthly Tyranny could compel the Wretched to live longer then they pleaed, if they had courage enough to die.—She pleaed her elf with the fancy, that to die in his ight (which he vowed if he were fale to her) would extract remore, and
pity from him; o much does Love miguide the Judgement of the mot prudent, that even in death they cheat themelves with vain hopes of a future atisfaction they can never be enible of.—In this humour he poted towards Saracua, but near the Gates was topped by a great pres of people? ome driving Beats of Carriage, laden with variety of Goods; others carrying on their backs, thoe whom Infancy or Age rendred uncapable to ait themelves; as if they fled from the fury of ome Foreign Invader, or from the mercilcs rage of a devouring flame. Loud Sighs, and doleful Groans, were all the anwers he could gain to her enquiry of the caue; long ue of Arms, and Virile exercie, had added much to her courage, in which he naturally outtriped her Sex: That (with a determined purpoe to behold the reaon of this Conternation) carried her through the moaking bloody Streets, which were trewed with dead and mangled Bodies (the ad marks of a Civil War) trait to the Pallace, amidt a thouand
Swords, and other Intruments of Death.—There he beheld the Gates hut, and the Queen and Princes out of a large Window, with begging Eyes, Hands, and Voices, in vain triving to infue compaion into the enraged Rabble, who roared inceantly, Give us our King! retore us our Prince! down with the Murtherers Zelidan not knowing the occaion of their Mutiny, nor enquiring now, but led by a generous principle of aiting the ditreed, made her way through the Croud, beckoning with her hands (for their noie made all peech ueles) for ilence, and liberty to pae; having attained to their Front, he faced them; and turning up her Beaver, hewed them a Countenance which never failed of gaining a repect from the mot Barbarous: The Grandeur of her Meen, and the Majetick weetnes of her Eyes, oon converted their confued Bauling to a ilent admiration: which he, whoe greatnes of Spirit was ever preent in the extremet' danger, trait improved to the advancement of her deigne,
the relief of the beieged Queen and Princes. Bowing her body then, with a charming reitles Grace peculiar only to her elf, thus he harangu'd them.—
div.q:
Valiant Souldiers! and mot worthy Citizens! whoe Valour and unquetioned Loyalty have till been the upport and glory of your own, as well as the envy of all neighbouring Princes; whoe free born hearts with joy ubmit to all decrees that bear the tamp of unbribed Jutice; why are thoe hining Weapons brandihed now againt weak Women? againt your undoubted lawful Queen? that ued to trike a Trembling horrour in your boldet Foes?—Are you injur'd in your Trade? are your due Liberties retrained?—Behold your good; your gracious Queen, ready to offer, nay intreat you to make your own Conditions. Behold Majety, in the form of an humble uppliant; have you the hearts of men, and look on this without being moved to duty and ubmiion?—Had your
Wives and Daughters been ravihed, your Etates given for a prey to the Inolent Souldier, had your Friends been lawlesly Imprioned, nay put to cruel undeerved deaths, (all which the great Gods forbid!) the deolation of your City, and killing of each other would be no recompence: Look round about you, behold your yet burning habitations, ee how cattered Limbs and torn Bodies pave your Streets; look how the detracted people flye thoe Buildings which the fire has pared, as if ome deadly Plague poes'd them, or the licentious Sword of a Barbarous Foe were at their backs.—Will you convert your tately Rooms to Graves? your City to a Deart? and your acred Temples to noiome Denns for Woolves? and bae Receptacles for Batts and Owls hrieking Harbingers of Death?—Go on! let every neighbour hide his Treacherous Dagger in his Friends heart conume each other bravely! and leave your Wives and Children a mierable Prey to the next Invader, that will vouchafe
afe to eize and drive them to perpetual Slavery.—I that am a tranger, cannot without Tears of Compaion foreee that deolation which you eek; my heart bleeds, and an univeral horrour runs through all my Veins;- if you are injured, my life hall be acrificed to your atisfaction.—
div.p:
Methinks I ee a noble Indignation in your eyes, and a true remore in Bluhes rie upon your Cheeks; how generous, how becoming does it look! Oh make hate to perfect your Repentance; let not future Chronicles deliver to ucceeding Ages, the Saracuans Swords were tained with the Slaughter of Poor, foraken, helples Women: But follow me to Safety, Wealth, and Honour: All that love their Liberty, their Countrys Peace, and the Honour of the great Gods, follow me!— Then cating her elf from her Hore, with her drawn Sword he began to lead them off.—
When one, that ought his particular Advantage from the general Ruine; that had fomented the Rebellion, as ome et Houes on fire, to Steal with more advantage and afety; cryed out, Companions! Friends! and Brothers! whither are you going, like Beats to the Sacrifice? And what is this bold impertinent Stranger that dares—There Zelidan put a full top to his Seditious Oration, and his Life together, by a thrut which pierced his heart: An Action which might have branded her with rahnes, (o boldly to hazard the Fury of a yet dicontented Multitude) but the Succes jutified its Prudence; (in uch extreams no middle paths are afe) for without a murmur all the ret followed her, marching over his body he had killed, to the Market-place; where with another Speech, he ent them pacified to their everal houes;—and by one of the mot undertanding, was informed, That the long abence and uppoed los of Alcidalis, and the late death of the King, were charged as Crimes upon the Ambitious Queen; and the Commonalty
tirred up by ome dicontented Spirits, had ought revenge by force of Armes: which caued that dreadful noie and detruction which he o happily had topped. Scarce was this information finihed, when a Meenger from the Queen entreated, That by his preence at the Court, he would aure that Life and Honour he had o generouly repriev'd. The joy Zelidan conceived to find the Prince abent, and as he believed contant to his Vows, (for the nimble faith of Lovers keeps equal pace with their wihes) obtained an eaie Pardon for all other injuries, and haten'd her to the ervice of the Queen: whom he found with the Princes her Daughter, and all the Train that ditracted time would allow, ready to receive her in the firt Court. The troubled thoughts that filled their Breats at their meeting, darted through their trembling Eyes, and in unettled colours pread themelves upon their Cheeks; though the caues were different, and a ecret to all but themelves. Zelidan (maugre all her goodnes) could not ee the fatal
intrument of her orrows; without ome trange emotion in her heart; nor could the Queen behold Zelidan, (whoe believed reidence at Tarentum, and her diguie, ecured Zelinda from the mot prying eyes) notwithtanding her Prudence, and experienced conduct, without diplaying to the trict oberver, ome ymptoms of that paion which had newly eized her: For the little audacious God of Love, had hovered till round Zelidan, and while he appeaed the mutinous Rabble, began a new and more dangerous inurrection in her Breat; ending from every word and action of this charming Amazon, a Golden Arrow to her heart, which her preent Dangers, nor the Grief for her yet carce breathles Husband, could defend her from. But the contraint he impoed upon her elf, in triving to conceal her Paion, expoed it more openly, epecially to Zelidan, who marked it with much atisfaction: hoping from thence an opportunity of a full and innocent revenge.—In hort, the amorous Queen received
him as a Meenger of Happines from Heaven: What recompence, (aid he) Illutrious Stranger! can we offer you, to whoe miraculous Relief we owe our Lives, and all we have to give? If the acred powers could admit a Rival in their worhip, our adoration to you were a jut debt. Madam, anwered the eigned Zelidan (bowing with a profound Reverence) to your own unequalled Virtues you owe your afety, and I the glory of my ucces; had not my indulgent Stars ent me to your aid, the Gods had by ome Miracle preerved in you the brightet Ornament of their Creation. (Many fine things were aid on this occaion, for they were both excellent at reparties and rejoynders, but my treacherous memory has lot them: Beides, I believe the repetition would be as tedious to the Reader, as to my elf; therefore I'le on to the matter, which was thus.) Zelidan was treated with all the Magnificence and Honour, gratitude and love could invent: and failed not by her dicreet conduct, to ettle a perfect correpondence again between the Court
and City; but her thoughts were till hankering after Alcidalis; purpoing after a little ret, and what light he could get by enquiry, to guide her on,—to earch the World, till he found him.—The Queen gave every hour new marks of her Paion, and ought occaion of dicovering it more plainly to Zelidan; who by all returns his different Quality would petmit, added Fewel to augment the Flame: And by the Sighs and Torments he oberved her uffer, (for her great heart was loath to make the firt addres; and he as poitively determined, as he had good reaon not to eae her by making the firt Courthip) received ome compenation for her former injurious treatment. The poor Princes was as unable to defend her elf from the aault of this Victorious Amazon, as the Queen, and with deepreentment oberved her Mothers Paion. Thus did the feigned Zelidan revenge, what the true Zelinda had endured: Love and Jealouie, was the buines of the Court; and the Queens uppoed Marriage with Zelidan,
the dicoure of the City. For the blind fears, or unreaonable wihes of the inconiderate Multitude, always anticipate the intentions of their Princes; transforming their very uppoed thoughts into Acts, which receive their publick cenure, or applaue, e're they have Being. The Queen oberving how carefully Zelidan declined all occaions of being attaqu'd, reolved to puh on her detiny, by a naked Declaration of her Love. In puruance of her intention, having commanded her Attendants to convenient ditance, while Zelidan was leading her in a walk of Oeamine, whoe interwoven Branches made o thick a Shade, that the Sun in its Meridian trength and lutre could not pierce them; with the gentle preings of his hand, reiterated Sighs, and peaking looks, having trove in vain, to prevent the hame of a plainer dicovery, at lat with broken interrupted Language, thus he pake;—

Is it poible, that the owner of o many
accomplihments as wait on the Illutrious Zelidan, hould be inenible of that noble Paion, which is to others the very caue of all hrave Actions, and the great reward at which they aim? has Love, that reigns o're all the World beides, no power in our Court? or is there no Object worthy of your Sighs? cating her eyes on thoe of Zelidan, which were fixed on the earth, he paued, and in a retles Agony waited his Anwer: which he had jut began, when a Gentleman, whoe earnet buines might well warrant his rude interruption of their Privacy, relieved him, by crying to the Queen, Save your elf, Madam! Save your elf by udden Flight, the Rebellious Citizens are again in Arms, and Headed by a deperate Stranger, like an impetuous Torrent that has o'reflowed its Banks, are rouling to the Palace, overthrowing all oppoition with their reitles Fury. Jutice and Liberty is Ecchoed through the Streets, but Blood & Michief is their aim. E're his unwelcome Meage was finihed, the cattered Courtiers came thronging about the Queen, and Zelidan, like
frighted Chickens eeking helter from the ravenous Kite. He trait attended the Queen into the Pallace auring her by the way, That his w ••• victory or death, hould evince the great deire he had to erve her. And taying not for her anwer, (which doubtles, would have been, That if he had any repect to her afety, he hould preerve it in that of his own; for her fate was o ineparably linked to his, that he could not urvive his death; or ome uch obliging thing) natched what Arms he oonet found, and ran to the Palace Gate, followed by a mall, but reolute Company of faithful Servants to the Queen. The Princes, who till then had mothered her Paion for Zelidan in the narrow limits of her Breat, depairing of ucces againt a Rival, which Duty forbad her to oppoe; and eeing what he prized dearer then her oul, hating to apparent death; took a Sword from the nearet Attendant, and followed Zelidan, hoping ome Fatal Blow would in his ight end her hopeles Paion, with her life. The brave Stranger
(for o his Acts declared him) that led on the Citizens, conquered all oppoition; till Zelidans arrival put a cheque to his growing victory. With an undaunted Meen he met him, and by her reolute Action, gave proof of a Courage far above her trength; but the invincible Alcidalis (for he it was) who had before conquered her in her own Province of Love, found but mall danger from her Arms. He received her firt charge on his Shield, and by everal marks taking her for Zelidan the famous Stranger, and as he thought pretender to his Crown; cryed out, If thou wilt be a King, go Reign among the hades! and boat thou dyedt by the hand of Alcidalis. At the beloved name of Alcidalis, Zelidan endeavoured to retreat, and dicover her elf; but in vain, for with uch fierce Blows he purued his Speech, that he fell Breathles at his Feet. The unhappy amorous Princes, triving with her feeble Arms to defend the fallen Zelidan, notwithtanding all Alcidalis could do to preerve her, fell a deplorable Sacrifice to the incened
Rabble, and dyed imbracing of Zelidan. The Queen, who from a Window beheld all this Action, at firt lamented not the death of her Daughter; but conidering her as a Rival, Sacrificed all entiments of Nature to the atisfaction of her jealouy. But eeing her beloved Zelidan Bleeding on the ground, extremity of Grief made her o inenible of all other coniderations, that he was about to precipitate her elf from the Window: But hope, which is the lat thing that leaves the unfortunate, made her till think it not impoible to recover him. She was running out to that purpoe, when Alcidalis, now a compleat Victor, was entring the Pallace: with all the ubmiion of a Pious Son, he met her; and declared, He would take all for Enemies, that failed to render her the Honour due to the Widow, and Mother of their King. Without taying, or anwering him at all; but with an upbraiding look, (where Rage and Compaion trove for Superiority) which eemed to call him a thouand Cruel Murthereres;
he abandoned her elf wholly to the impule of her Paion, and cating her body on thoe of Zelidan and the Princes her Daughter, he divided her Kies and Lamentations between them: 'Till exceive orrow, like a Tyrannical Uurper, eized and oppreed all her Vitals: By its ad weight reducing her to a tate as deplorable, and void of life, as theirs whom he grieved for. Never had Love and Grief a greater Sacrifice then here, nor miery more powerful Arguments to gain compaion from the mot obdurate hearts: (here is a large Field for the Author to expatiate on the viciitude of humane things; but the Gentle Reader would think him very inhumane, nay in my Concience acceary to their Murthers, if he uffered three of the mot Illutrious Perons in the World, to lye neglected on the ground, and dye for want of careful attendance, while he was hewing his Common-place Wit; therefore he hatens to their relief, with reolution to ave them all if he can:) Alcidalis took the Queen in his
Arms, while others performed the ame ervice to the Princes and Zelidan; conveying them to their everal apartments; the uncertain Multitude, that ome few Minutes before breathed nothing but death and damnation againt them; now followed them Houling and Groaning. All the Arts and trength of Phyick were diligently applyed, which retored ome weak ymptoms of life in Zelidan; and thoe were carefully Cherihed; but the unfortunate Princes was irrevocably dead. The Queens Swouning being only the effect of a vehement urprizing Paion, death oon was beaten off, and his pale preading Enigns rufled up by her returning Senes: But life came accompanied with all thoe killing Griefs that waited on its exile, which like the envyed Favourites of ome weak unhappy Prince (for forrows oon ininuate themelves into the hearts affection) raied new Commotions among the ouls dicontented faculties, and the oppreed Senes, (thoe neceary Subjects and upport of Life) which were
like to prove as fatal as the former; had not the News of Zelidans hopeful Recovery repreed their Violence, by the removal of the caue.—Weak as he was, he caued her elf to be removed to his apartment.—But, Gods! what a univeral amazement eized the Queen, and all the Attendants, to find their Champion was a Woman? For o her welling Breats declared, which by undreing her, the better to apyly their neceary aid, were dicovered. Her Senes in a little time were perfectly retored; and 'twas difficult for the mot curious oberver to determine, whether the Queen or Zelinda (for o we mut call her, now hes dicovered) was in the greatet confuion; after they had a long time gazed upon each other, the Queen finding in the transformed Zelidan, the well known Beauty and Meen of the perecuted Zelinda; lifting her eyes to Heaven cryed out; I yeild! jut Gods, I yeild to my inexorable detiny! Ab Zelinda! thy injuries have been too well revenged.—Having aid this, e'r Zelinda could anwer, he retired.
Love being now wholly exextinct, Nature reumed her power, and carried her to the apartment of the Princes, where with uch moving paion he deplored her los, that the mot inible were forced to ympathize with her. The News of Zelidans Transformation, flew traight through the Pallace, and the extraordinarines of the change, raied a Curioity in Alcidalis to behold her, for he had not heard that it was Zelinda. The Meengrr he ent to obtain that liberty, entered her Chamber, jut as one was going from her to entreat the favour which he ought. The Prince full of hame for his Victory over a Woman, hatened to beg her pardon; When he entered, his Attendants repectively withdrew to the furthet part of the Room. Neither the Palenes her los of Blood had planted on her Cheeks, nor their long eparation, could hinder the dicovery of the true Zelinda at firt ight:—So perfectly had love engraven her Image in his heart. What Pen can decribe the Violence of their differnt Paions
which then Tyrannized in this Princes Breat? Shame and grief for wounding her he prized above his Life, and joy that he urvived, and was in a place where he was now ole Mater and able to give and receive the highet proofs of a mutual, unalterable Love, (like meeting Tydes, whoe oppoed forces change wift running Streams a while into a fixed Calme) reduced him to a tate of inenibility:—Without Speech or motion, he beheld her Such extaies are the uual effects of udden Joys or Grief; the heart being urprized, and oppreed with unexpected Events, all the Vital Spirits croud o fat to its aitance, that they often caue that ruine Nature ends them to prevent. As ome, whoe Animal Spirits are obtructed, and as it were mothered by the indigeted Vapours, which from the Stomach fume into the Brain, and a while deprive them of the benefits of Life, (as interpoing Clouds obcure the Suns lutre) retain their Senes, but want power to imploy them; uch the preent State of Alcidalis was,
he knew what he ought to peak, and act, but the greatnes of his Love, and violence of his deires, took from him all ability of utterance; till Zelinda, whoe condition much reembled his, fearing his ilence proceeded from ome change in his affection, thus began.—
div.q: Is this the kind reception Alcidalis gives the unfortunate Zelinda? do all the dangers I have pat, and all my contant Love, merit this cold return? Great Gods! have you preerved me from o many various Deaths, to perih here? here in the only Haven, where I had depoited my lat hopes of aured afety? Oh Alcidalis! let thy Sword give me a peedy and more welcome death then thy didain!—
div.p: Here cating himelf on the Bed, and imbracing her, he could get out no more but, Oh my dearet Zelinda! and was relaping again into his former extaie; which overcoming, with much difficulty he proceeded.—
div.q: Your afety and your love (my adored Zelinda!) are bleings too great to be received at once, with les concern: Since your los, in blindnes to all other objects of delight, I have wandred ore the World; pardon me, if I could not meet the firt appearance of my Glorious Sun, without amazement. Give me, ye Divine Powers! proportioned trength to bear my Happines, let like a tarving man, while I too greedily receive it, that hatens my death which only can retore my fainting life.—
Then do you yet love me? (cryed the overjoyed Princes;) and will the King, keep thoe vowes which Alcidalis made to the then Happy Zelinda?—
For ever! for ever! (anwered the tranported Alcidalis) the enjoyment of my adored Zelinda, is more then ten thouand Empires.—
Ah Sir, (aid he) but interet of State.—
div.p: State! (cryed Alcidalis) my Zelinda is all all to me, I would not thank the Gods for a Crown, but to lay it at her Feet. Then turning to the Attendants which had now filled the Room, (impatience of beholding their long lot Prince, bringing them thither from all parts) raiing his voice, he cryed out: He is a Traytor, and the Mortal Enemy of Alcidalis, that will not kneel and Petition the excellent Zelinda to be his Queen; whoe Beauty and Virtues, merit the Empire of the Univere. The Gods (to whom I pay all reverence) hall never, but by death, Divorce me from thy Arms.—Were I Racked to ten thouand peices, as every part of a broken Mirrour preents an entire face, in every part of Alcidalis, would appear the bright Image of my adored Zelinda.

Then they renewed their Embraces and mutual Vows; asking and anwearing twenty everal Quetion • at once. She related all her Adventures from her departure from Barcelona
till that intant: which Alcidalis requited with his Story, how he ought her in Italy, (but omitted his intrigue with the Dutches of Tarentum) and at Sardignia, where meeting the News of his Fathers death, the preervation of his Crown hatened him to Spain; But with a reolute determination to imploy all his new power, in earch of Zelinda: How, near Saracua, by ome faithful Nobility to whom he made himelf known, and who received him with marks of unexepreible atisfaction, he was informed of the Actions of Zelidan, his interet with the Queen, and his uppoed deign of Marrying her, and uurping the Crown. This gave Honour a while the preheminence of Love, and led him in the Head of thoe Friends the hortnes of the time could get together, to this mitaken Revenge, and real Happines.—

The Queen notwithtanding all the ubmiive importunity of Alcidalis and all the aurances of Power and
Honour he could give her, would not be diverted from a reolution he had made, of retiring to a Religious Houe, there to pas the remainder of her now hated life.

After the Funeral of the Princes her Daughter was with all Ceremonious, Pomp celebrated he performed her Vow, and was accompanied to the place of her retirememt, with a Magnificence becoming that Solemn occaion.
To that olemnity immediatly ucceeded the Coronation, and Marriagof Alcidalis and Zelinda.
The day with all imaginable Circumtances of an univeral joy was finihed.

After which, Gentle Reader! (I may afely call you o now, for I am ure you are tyr'd as well as I) you may uppoe the long-wihed night are riv'd, though very lazily in the Opinion of the King and Queen: And you
may uppoe their impatient Love hatened them to Bed; And what followed, you may uppoe too, if you pleae; for I have more Civility then to peak what I think: but as the mot Ingenious Sir John Suckling aid.

q.l: What is this, who can tell?
But I believe it was no more,
Then thou and I have done before.

div.p: I have naturally o much kindnes for Lovers, that I will without further diturbance leave them to their private Banquet; and if no other Pen raies them, they hall lye there till Dooms, day.
